revision.text:
{{Year nav topic5|1680|music}}
The year '''1680 in music''' involved some significant events.
==Events== *[[Arcangelo Corelli]] begins his friendship with Cristiano Farinelli. *[[Antonio Stradivari]] sets up his own business in Cremona. *[[John Blow]] is forced out of his job as organist at [[Westminster Abbey]], to make room for [[Henry Purcell]].{{Citation needed|date=August 2017}} *[[Georg Muffat]] goes to Italy to study organ with [[Bernardo Pasquini]]. *[[Johann Philipp Krieger]] becomes Kapellmeister of the court at [[Weissenfels]]. *First record of the [[marimba]] in [[Guatemala]].{{Citation needed|date=August 2017}}
==Published popular music== *
==Classical music== *[[Dieterich Buxtehude]] – ''[[Membra Jesu Nostri]]'' *[[Marc-Antoine Charpentier]] – ''Filius prodigus''
==[[Opera]]== *[[Pietro Simone Agostini]] – ''Il ratto delle Sabine'' *[[Jean-Baptiste Lully]] – ''[[Proserpine (Lully)|Proserpine]]'' *[[Antonio Sartorio]] – ''La Flora'' *[[Alessandro Scarlatti]] – [[L'honestà negli amori]]''
==Births== *[[May 6]] – [[Jean-Baptiste Stuck]], cellist and composer (died 1755) *[[November 18]] (baptised) – [[Jean-Baptiste Loeillet of London|Jean-Baptiste Loeillet]], composer (died 1730) *[[December 11]] – [[Emanuele d'Astorga]], composer (died 1736) *''date unknown'' – François Campion, guitarist and composer
==Deaths== *March – [[Johann Heinrich Schmelzer]], violinist (born 1623) *[[May 31]] – [[Joachim Neander]], hymn-writer (b. 1650) *[[September 10]] – [[Baldassare Ferri]], ''castrato'' singer (born 1610) *[[October 13]] **[[Lelio Colista]], composer and lutenist (b. 1629) **[[François Roberday]], organist and composer (b. 1624) *[[December 10]] – [[Marco Uccellini]], violinist and composer *[[December 30]] – [[Antonio Sartorio]], composer (born 1630) *''date unknown'' **[[Kancherla Gopanna]], composer of Carnatic music (born c.1620) **[[Maria Francesca Nascinbeni]], composer (born c.1640)
[[Category:1680 in music| ]] [[Category:17th century in music]] [[Category:Years in music]]

page.title: A Landscape with a Ruined Castle and a Church

revision.comment: added [[Category:Churches in art]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox artwork | image_file = Jacob Isaacksz. van Ruisdael - An Extensive Landscape with a Ruined Castle and a Village Church - WGA20493.jpg | caption = | painting_alignment = | image_size = 300px | title = A Landscape with a Ruined Castle and a Church | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = [[Jacob van Ruisdael]] | year = 1665 | material = | height_metric = 109 | width_metric = 146 | length_metric = | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_metric = | diameter_imperial = | dimensions = | metric_unit = cm<!--don't leave this parameter blank—either don't include it, or include the default cm. Not including it will default it to cm.--> | imperial_unit = in<!--don't leave this parameter blank—either don't include it, or include the default in. Not including it will default it to in.--> | city = [[London]] | museum = [[National Gallery]] | coordinates = <!-- Only use for the exact coordinates of the artwork itself (and only where known) and not for the coordinates of the museum. Leave blank if coordinates are not known. --> | owner = }} '''''A Landscape with a Ruined Castle and a Church''''' (c. 1665) is an [[oil painting|oil]] on canvas painting by the [[Netherlands|Dutch]] landscape painter [[Jacob van Ruisdael]]. It is an example of [[Dutch Golden Age painting]] and is now in the collection of the [[National Gallery]]. == Description == This painting was documented by [[Hofstede de Groot]] in 1911, who wrote; "136. Landscape with Cornfields, and Sheep and Figures. [[John Smith (art historian)|Sm. 214.]] A far-reaching view across an open plain varied with woods, meadows, and cornfields, villages and churches amid trees, cottages and windmills. In front are the ruins of a castle with a stagnant moat, fringed with trees and underwood. On the left a winding road passes a cornfield with sheaves and a group of trees and is lost in the distance. A shepherd sits on the old castle-wall, conversing with a youth seated on the ground, near a dog and three sheep. On a bastion, on the other side, are three sheep ; in a breach of the bastion stands a man. On a pool are three swans. The figures and cattle are by [[Adriaen van de Velde|A. van de Velde]]. A thunderstorm has just passed over. In the sky are masses of rolling cloud, through which sunbeams fall on windmills in the distance. The rest of the landscape is in partial shadow. "This capital picture may be cited as a chef d'oeuvre of the artist in this peculiar department of landscape-painting " (Sm.). [Compare 775, 776.] Canvas, 43 inches by 57 inches. Exhibited at Manchester, 1857, No. 699, by R. Sanderson. Sale. [[Jan Gildemeester]], Amsterdam, June 11, 1800, No. 190 (315 florins, Tays). In the collection of the Marquis de Marialva, Paris, 1825 ; bought privately by Sm. Sales. John Smith, London, 1828 (£472 : 10s.). Abrahams, London, 1831 (£275). In the collection of Richard Sanderson, London, 1835 (Sm.). Sale. R. Sanderson, London, June 17, 1848 (£504, Brown) ; but apparently bought in, for it was in the Sanderson collection in 1854 ([[Gustav Friedrich Waagen|Waagen]], ii. 288), and was lent from it to Manchester in 1857. "<ref>[https://archive.org/stream/catalogueraisonn04hofsuoft#page/48/mode/1up Entry 136 for ''''Landscape with Cornfields, and Sheep and Figures''] in Hofstede de Groot, 1911</ref>
This scene is very similar to other paintings Ruisdael made in this period. <gallery> File:Jacob Isaaksz. van Ruisdael 018.jpg|Cat. nr. 36, called ''A View of [[Beverwijk]]'', also in the National Gallery File:Jacob van Ruisdael - An extensive landscape with an artist sketching by a ruin, a rowboat and cottages with a church beyond.jpg|Cat. nr. 775 referred to above, called ''The Ruins of a Fort''; Sold at Christie's in 1998
</gallery>
== References == {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Paintings of ruins by Jacob van Ruisdael}} *[https://rkd.nl/en/explore/images/51560 Weids landschap met kasteelruïne en kerktoren, ca. 1665-1670 (Slive 2001; zie bronnen)] in the [[RKD]] *[https://archive.org/stream/catalogueraisonn06smituoft#page/67/mode/1up 214. A Landscape] in Smith's catalogue raisonné volume 6, 1835, and illustrated [https://archive.org/stream/catalogueraisonn06smituoft#page/n90/mode/1up here]
{{Jacob van Ruisdael}} {{Authority control}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox artist | name = Alexander Tikhonovich Pushnin | image = Pushnin-Alexander-Tikhonovich-dav03bw.jpg | imagesize = 200px | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = March 28, 1921 | birth_place = [[Morshansk]], [[Tambov Oblast|Tambov Province]], [[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic|Soviet Russia]] | death_date = September 5, 1991 | death_place = [[Leningrad]], [[USSR]] | field = [[Painting]] | citizenship = [[USSR]] | nationality = [[Russians|Russian]] | training = [[Repin Institute of Arts]] | movement = [[Realism (visual art)|Realism]] | works = | patrons = | awards = }}
'''Alexander Tikhonovich Pushnin''' ({{lang-ru|Алекса́ндр Ти́хонович Пушни́н}}; March 28, 1921, city of Morshansk, Tambov Province, Soviet Russia – September 5, 1991, Leningrad, USSR) was a Soviet, Russian painter, [[Doctor of Arts|Doctor of Art-criticism]], professor of the [[Repin Institute of Arts]], lived and worked in [[Leningrad]], member of the [[Leningrad Union of Artists]],<ref>''Directory of Members of the Union of Artists of USSR. Volume 2.''- Moscow: Soviet artist, 1979. - p.248.</ref> regarded as one of the representatives of the [[Leningrad School of Painting|Leningrad school of painting]],<ref>''Sergei V. Ivanov. Unknown Socialist Realism. The Leningrad School.''- Saint Petersburg: NP-Print Edition, 2007. – pp.9, 27, 152, 204, 367, 384, 388, 389, 393-396, 398, 399, 403, 411, 413, 414, 416, 417, 419, 421.</ref> most famous for his portrait and historical painting.
== Biography == Alexander Pushnin was born March 28, 1921, in the city [[Morshansk]], [[Tambov Oblast|Tambov Province]], [[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic|Soviet Russia]].
In 1943, Pushnin entered the painting department of the [[Repin Institute of Arts|Leningrad Institute of Painting, Sculpture and Architecture]]. He studied of Ivan Stepashkin, [[Mikhail Avilov]], [[Yuri Neprintsev]], [[Aleksandr Gerasimov (painter)|Aleksandr Gerasimov]].
In 1950, Pushnin graduated from [[Repin Institute of Arts|Leningrad Institute of Painting, Sculpture and Architecture named after Ilya Repin]] in [[Rudolf Frentz]] personal Art Studio. His graduation work was a historical painting named "[[Vladimir Lenin]] [[Kazan State University|in Kazan University]]", dedicated to Lenin's participation in student demonstrations.<ref>''Anniversary Directory graduates of Saint Petersburg State Academic Institute of Painting, Sculpture, and Architecture named after Ilya Repin, Russian Academy of Arts. 1915 - 2005''. - Saint Petersburg: Pervotsvet Publishing House, 2007. p. 63.</ref>
Since 1948, Pushnin has participated in Art Exhibitions. He painted portraits, genre and historical compositions, landscapes, worked also in drawing and watercolors. His style featured a powerful pictorial language, a broad style of painting, sharp composition, interest in the unusual angles. His solo exhibition was in [[Leningrad]] in 1982.
Since 1950, Pushnin was a member of the [[Leningrad Union of Artists]]. He was [[Doctor of Arts|Doctor of Art-criticism]] (1952) and Professor of the [[Repin Institute of Arts|Leningrad Institute of Painting, Sculpture and Architecture named after Ilya Repin]] (1986).
Pushnin died on September 5, 1991, in Leningrad at the seventy-first year of life. His paintings reside in [[State Russian Museum]], in Art museums and private collections in Russia,<ref>''Sergei V. Ivanov. Unknown Socialist Realism. The Leningrad School.'' - Saint Petersburg: NP-Print Edition, 2007. – pp. 6-7.</ref> England, USA, China, Japan, France,<ref>''Peinture Russe. Catalogue.'' - Paris: Drouot Richelieu, 26 Avril, 1991. - pp. 7, 46-47.</ref> and other countries.
==See also== * [[Leningrad School of Painting]] * [[List of Russian artists]] * [[List of 20th-century Russian painters]] * [[List of painters of Saint Petersburg Union of Artists]] * [[Saint Petersburg Union of Artists]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
== Gallery ==

Catalogue.'' - Paris: Drouot Richelieu, 26 Avril, 1991. - p. 7,46-47. * ''Sergei V. Ivanov. Unknown Socialist Realism. The Leningrad School.'' - Saint Petersburg: NP-Print Edition, 2007. – pp. 9, 27, 152, 204, 367, 384, 388, 389, 393-396, 398, 399, 403, 411, 413, 414, 416, 417, 419, 421. {{ISBN|5-901724-21-6}}, {{ISBN|978-5-901724-21-7}}. * ''Anniversary Directory graduates of Saint Petersburg State Academic Institute of Painting, Sculpture, and Architecture named after Ilya Repin, Russian Academy of Arts. 1915–2005''. – Saint-Petersburg: Pervotsvet Publishing House, 2007. P.63.
== External links == {{Commons category|Alexander Pushnin}} * [http://www.leningradartist.com/ ''Alexander Pushnin on the "Unknown Socialist Realism. Quests and Discoveries"''.] * [http://www.leningradartist.com/outline.htm ''Sergei V. Ivanov. The Leningrad School of painting. Historical outline.''] * [http://www.leningradartist.com/chronology.htm ''Chronology of the Leningrad School of painting. ''] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7OZ9UDwgyuo ''Alexander Pushnin on VIDEO "Portrait painting of 1920-1990s. The Leningrad School. Part 1"''] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QI_XR1t7UnE ''Alexander Pushnin on VIDEO "Portrait in painting of 1920-1990s. The Leningrad School. Part 3"'']

revision.text:
{{Infobox Artwork | image_file= Trufanov-AIC-chu21b.jpg | backcolor=#FBF5DF | painting_alignment=right | image_size=350px | title=Blast Furnace Men | artist=[[Mikhail Trufanov|Mikhail P. Trufanov]] | year=1954 | type= | height_metric= | width_metric= | height_imperial= | width_imperial= | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city= [[Moscow]] | museum=[[Tretyakov gallery]] }}
The '''All-Union Art Exhibition (Moscow, 1957)''' devoted to the 40th anniversary of the [[October Revolution]] ({{lang-ru|italic=yes|Всесоюзная художественная выставка, посвящённая 40-летию Великой Октябрьской социалистической революции}}) was one of the largest art exhibitions in Soviet history. Exhibition took place in [[Moscow Manege|Manezh Exhibition Hall]] from November 5, 1957 to May, 1958.<ref>''Грабарь И. Заметки о живописи на Всесоюзной художественной выставке 1957 года.'' // Искусство, 1958, №1. С.14-17.</ref>
== History and Organization == The organization and preparation of the All-Union Exhibition engaged a specially formed Exhibition Committee, which consisted of the most authoritative art experts. It published an illustrated catalog of the exhibition.<ref>''Всесоюзная художественная выставка, посвященная 40-летию Великой Октябрьской социалистической революции. Живопись. Скульптура. Графика. Работы художников театра и кино. Каталог.'' — М: Министерство культуры СССР, 1957.</ref> In addition to Manezh, the exposition has been deployed in other exhibition halls of Moscow: in the USSR Academy of Arts, in the House of Artists, in the Exhibition Hall of the Union of Artists of the USSR, and in other halls of the Soviet capital.<ref>''Выставки советского изобразительного искусства. Справочник. Том 5. 1954—1958 годы.'' — М: Советский художник, 1981. — с.370-379.</ref> In total, the Exhibition displayed more than 8,000 works of art, including more than 1,600 paintings, 700 sculptures, and 2,000 graphic works.<ref>''На Всесоюзной художественной выставке'' // Правда, 1957, 8 декабря.</ref> The Exhibition was visited by over 1 million people. Many art works were purchased for the largest Soviet art museums, including the [[Russian Museum]], the [[Tretyakov Gallery]], and others. After the Exhibition in Moscow five traveling exhibitions were organized, which were shown in the capitals of the Union Republics and major cities. Ninety art works were presented at the [[Expo '58|World's Fair]] in Brussels, Belgium in the Soviet department in 1958.<ref>''Журнал "Искусство"''. 1958, №3, С.77</ref>
==Contributing artists== A total of 2,142 artists of all Soviet republics took part in the Exhibition: painters, sculptors, graphics artists, masters of arts and crafts, and artists of theater and cinema; including [[Mikhail Anikushin]], [[Dmitry Belyaev (artist)|Dmitry Belyaev]], [[Olga Bogaevskaya]], [[Aleksandr Gerasimov (painter)|Aleksandr Gerasimov]], [[Sergey Vasilyevich Gerasimov|Sergey Gerasimov]], [[Igor Grabar]], [[Aleksei Gritsai]], [[Alexander Deyneka]], [[Alexei Eriomin]], [[Boris Ioganson]], [[Lev Kerbel]], [[Pavel Korin]], [[Vladimir Malevsky]], [[Matvey Manizer]], [[Evsey Moiseenko]], [[Yuri Neprintsev]], [[Andrey Mylnikov]], [[Aleksandr Ivanovich Laktionov|Alexander Laktionov]], [[Dmitriy Nalbandyan]], [[Ernst Neizvestny]], [[Arkady Plastov]], [[Nikolai Timkov]], [[Mikhail Trufanov]], [[Yuri Tulin]], [[Vsevolod Bazhenov]], [[Piotr Belousov]], [[Nikolai Galakhov]], [[Oleg Eremeev]], [[Maya Kopitseva]], [[Boris Korneev]], [[Engels Kozlov]], [[Anatoli Levitin]], [[Boris Lavrenko]], [[Andrei Mylnikov]], [[Dmitry Oboznenko]], [[Victor Oreshnikov]], [[Alexander Nikolayevich Samokhvalov|Alexander Samokhvalov]], [[Gleb Savinov]], [[Alexander Mikhailovich Semionov|Alexander Semionov]], [[Joseph Serebriany]], [[Vladimir Serov (artist)|Vladimir Serov]], [[Mikhail Trufanov]], [[Boris Ugarov]], [[Nina Veselova]], [[Yevgeny Vuchetich]], [[Sergei Yefimovich Zakharov|Sergei Zakharov]], and many other most prominent Soviet artists.<ref>''Всесоюзная художественная выставка, посвященная 40-летию Великой Октябрьской социалистической революции. Живопись. Скульптура. Графика. Работы художников театра и кино. Каталог.'' М., Министерство культуры СССР, 1957.</ref>
== Contributed Artworks == [[File:Moscow Manege - 2.jpg|thumb|350px|[[Moscow Manege|Moscow Manezh Exhibition Hall]]. 2008]]
For display at the Exhibition were selected art works created in 1957, as well as some earlier works. Many of them were previously shown at the city, regional and republic art exhibitions in 1957. Many of them were subsequently found in the collections of Soviet art museums, as well as domestic and foreign galleries and collectors. Among them there were paintings of historical genres such as ''Volley "Aurora"'' by [[Aleksandr Gerasimov (painter)|Aleksandr Gerasimov]], ''"First Cavalry Army"'' by [[Evsey Moiseenko]],<ref>''Недошивин Г. Окрыляющие перспективы. На Всесоюзной художественной выставке'' // Правда, 1957, 18 декабря.</ref> ''"For the Soviet Power"'' by [[Sergey Vasilyevich Gerasimov|Sergey Gerasimov]], ''"Lenin proclaims Soviet power"'' by [[Boris Ioganson]], ''"Declaration of the Soviet Power"'' by [[Alexander Nikolayevich Samokhvalov|Alexander Samokhvalov]], ''"Decree on Peace"'' and ''"Decree on the Land"'' by [[Vladimir Serov (artist)|Vladimir Serov]], ''"Lena. 1912"'' by [[Yuri Tulin]], and others.
The theme of modernity and the modern image of the country were figuratively revealed in the works ''"Furnaceman"'' and ''"Blast furnace men"'' by [[Mikhail Trufanov]], ''"Industrial Lights"'' by [[Vsevolod Bazhenov]], ''"In the Garden"'' by [[Olga Bogaevskaya]], ''"Blacksmiths"'' by [[Alexander Deyneka]], ''"North pier"'' by [[Alexei Eriomin]], ''"Grandfather and granddaughter"'' by [[Vasily Yefanov]], and others.
== Acknowledgment == On December 7, 1957 the Exhibition was visited by the leaders of the Soviet Union [[Nikita Khrushchev]], [[Yekaterina Furtseva]], [[Leonid Brezhnev]], [[Alexei Kosygin]], [[Anastas Mikoyan]], and [[Mikhail Suslov]].<ref>''На Всесоюзной художественной выставке'' // Правда, 1957, 8 декабря.</ref> The work and results of the All-Union Art Exhibition were widely covered in the press<ref>''Недошивин Г. Окрыляющие перспективы. На Всесоюзной художественной выставке'' // Правда, 1957, 18 декабря.</ref><ref>''К новым большим свершениям'' // Ленинградская правда. 1958, 12 января.</ref><ref>''На Всесоюзной художественной выставке'' // Правда, 1957, 8 декабря.</ref> and literature on Soviet fine art.<ref>''Художники народов СССР. Биобиблиографический словарь. Т. 1-4.''. М., Искусство, 1970-1995.</ref><ref>''Выставки советского изобразительного искусства. Справочник. Том 5. 1954—1958 годы.'' М., Советский художник, 1981. C.385-387.</ref><ref>''Баршова И. Н., Сазонова К. К. . Александр Самохвалов.'' Л., Художник РСФСР, 1963. С.46.</ref><ref>''Леонова Н. Г. Глеб Александрович Савинов.'' Л., Художник РСФСР, 1988. С.48—51.</ref><ref>''Ярослав Сергеевич Николаев. Сборник материалов и каталог выставки произведений''. Л., Художник РСФСР, 1986. С.43, 55, 68, 92—93.</ref>
== See also == * [[Soviet art]] * [[1957 in fine arts of the Soviet Union]] * [[Fine Art of Leningrad]] * [[Leningrad School of Painting]] * [[Saint Petersburg Union of Artists]] * [[Socialist realism]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
== Sources == * ''Всесоюзная художественная выставка, посвященная 40-летию Великой Октябрьской социалистической революции. Живопись. Скульптура. Графика. Работы художников театра и кино. Каталог.'' М., Министерство культуры СССР, 1957. * ''На Всесоюзной художественной выставке'' // Правда, 1957, 8 декабря. * ''Грабарь И. Заметки о живописи на Всесоюзной художественной выставке 1957 года.'' // Искусство, 1958, №1. С.14-17. * ''Недошивин Г. Окрыляющие перспективы. На Всесоюзной художественной выставке'' // Правда, 1957, 18 декабря. * ''Полищук Э. Советская армия в произведениях художников. На Всесоюзной художественной выставке'' // Искусство, 1958, №1. С.42-46. * ''Никифоров Б. Черты нового в жанровой картине наших дней'' // Искусство, 1958, №2. С.9-18. * ''Прытков В. Новые работы советских пейзажистов'' // Искусство, 1958, №2. С.19-28. * ''Журнал "Искусство"''. 1958, №3, С.77 * ''Выставки советского изобразительного искусства. Справочник. Т.5. 1954—1958 гг.'' М., Советский художник, 1981. С.370-379. * ''Справочник членов Ленинградской организации Союза художников РСФСР.'' Л., Художник РСФСР, 1980. * ''Художники народов СССР. Биобиблиографический словарь. Т.1-4.''. М., Искусство, 1970-1995. * ''Справочник членов Союза художников СССР. Том 1,2.'' М., Советский художник, 1979. * ''Time for Change. The Art of 1960-1985 in the Soviet Union''. - Saint Petersburg: State Russian Museum, 2006. * ''Sergei V. Ivanov. Unknown Socialist Realism. The Leningrad School.''- Saint Petersburg: NP-Print Edition, 2007. {{ISBN|5-901724-21-6}}, {{ISBN|978-5-901724-21-7}}. * ''Юбилейный Справочник выпускников Санкт-Петербургского академического института живописи, скульптуры и архитектуры имени И. Е. Репина Российской Академии художеств. 1915—2005.'' СПб., Первоцвет, 2007.

revision.text:
[[File:Pantone Birds by Pinar Yoldas.jpg|thumb|Feathers of "Pantone Birds" which are adapt to plastic environment and evolved to take the colours of plastic bottle caps they have been eating for years.]]
'''An Ecosystem of Excess''' is an art project by artist and researcher [[Pinar Yoldas]]. The project addresses a series of ecological problems such as man-made [[extreme environments]], [[consumer capitalism]], [[plastic pollution]] and [[threatened species]] in the age of the [[Anthropocene]]. Yoldas was awarded the Ernst Schering Foundation Arts & Culture Grant for her project, and An Ecosystem of Excess was premiered in Ernst Schering Project Space in Berlin in 2014.<ref name="Ernst Schering">[http://www.scheringstiftung.de/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2761%3Apinar-yoldas-an-ecosystem-of-excess&catid=65%3Arueckschau&Itemid=151&lang=en "Pinar Yoldas: An Ecosystem of Excess"], ''Ernst Schering Foundation'', Retrieved 27 November 2017.</ref>
The project is an artistic imagination of a post-anthropocene [[ecosystem]] where non-human living creatures are evolved to digest plastic while human species goes extinct. It portrays the future story of alien life forms that emerge from the [[Great Pacific garbage patch]], in the form of a [[dystopian]] re-staging of [[Abiogenesis]]. For the project, Yoldas worked with [[marine biologist]] [[Sylvia Earle]] .<ref name="Style Park">[https://www.stylepark.com/en/news/welcome-to-the-plastivorizene "Welcome to the Plastivorizene"], ''Stylepark'', Retrieved 27 November 2017.</ref>
An Ecosystem of Excess is a work informed by scientific research which confirms the emergence of new bacteria which adapt to plastic environments or what is scientifically called the [[plastisphere]], yet, it is a product of speculative fiction that takes inspiration but departs from science.<ref name="Aksioma">[http://aksioma.org/ecosystem.of.excess "Pinar Yoldas: An Ecosystem of Excess"], ''Aksioma'', Retrieved 27 November 2017.</ref><ref name="Environmental Science and Technology Journal">{{cite journal|last1=Zettler|first1=Erik R.|last2=Mincer|first2=Tracy J.|last3=Amaral-Zettler|first3=Linda A.|title=Life in the "Plastisphere": Microbial Communities on Plastic Marine Debris|journal=Environmental Science and Technology|date=June 7, 2013|volume=47|issue=13|pages=7137–7146|doi=10.1021/es401288x|url=http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/es401288x/|accessdate=27 November 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Goldstein|first1=Miriam C.|last2=Rosenberg|first2=Marci|last3=Cheng|first3=Lanna|title=Increased oceanic microplastic debris enhances oviposition in an endemic pelagic insect|journal=Biology Letters|date=May 9, 2012|volume=8|issue=5|pages=817–820.|doi=10.1098/rsbl.2012.0298|pmc=3440973|accessdate=}}</ref> It points to evolution and how this process is indirectly altered by human intervention in the age of [[Anthropocene]].<ref name="Digicult">[http://www.digicult.it/news/shaping-alternative-futures-interview-pinar-yoldas/ "Shaping Alternative Futures: Interview with Pinar Yoldas], ''Digicult'', Retrieved 27 November 2017.</ref> The work involves a creative exaggeration of scientific facts, and more generally, a research about "the collaborative potential between art and biological sciences."<ref name="UCLA">[http://cdh.ucla.edu/event/dma-lecture-pinar-yoldas/ "Digital Humanities Lecture: Pinar Yoldas"], ''UCLA Center for Digital Humanities'', Retrieved 27 November 2017.</ref> Artist-theorists [[Zach Blas]] and Christopher O'Leary describe the work as a design of "synthetic biological systems as a living critique of our society." <ref>{{cite book|last1=Blas|first1=Zach|last2=O'Leary|first2=Christopher|title=Speculative (exhibition catalogue)|date=2011|page=114|pages=|url=https://books.google.com/?id=igQ9AwAAQBAJ&pg=PA114#v=onepage&q&f=false|isbn=9781257799800}}</ref>
The project has been exhibited internationally, in venues such as [[ZKM]] [[Center for Art and Media Karlsruhe]] (2014),<ref name="ZKM">[http://zkm.de/en/event/2015/10/globale-exo-evolution "GLOBALE: Exo-Evolution"] ''ZKM'', Retrieved 27 November 2017.</ref> Aksioma Institute for Contemporary Arts in Slovenia (2014),<ref name="Aksioma"/> NAMOC National Art Museum of Beijing (2014), Polytech Museum Moscow (2015), ISCP [[International Studio & Curatorial Program]] in New York (2015),<ref name="ISCP">[http://iscp-nyc.org/event/aqueous-earth "Aqueous Earth"] ''ISCP'', Retrieved 27 November 2017.</ref> National Taiwan Museum of Fine Arts (2016),<ref name="NTMOFA">[http://english.ntmofa.gov.tw/English/ShowInfomation_1.aspx?SN=4736 "Regeneration Movement: Rethinking Technology in the Digital Age"] ''NTMOFA'', Retrieved 26 November 2017.</ref> BOZAR Center for Fine Arts in Brussels (2017)<ref name="BOZAR">[http://www.bozar.be/en/activities/130852-feat "Future Emerging Art and Technology"] ''BOZAR'', Retrieved 28 November 2017</ref> and Calit2 Gallery at [[UC San Diego]] (2017)<ref name="Calit2">[http://calit2.net/newsroom/release.php?id=2800 "Artist Offers Dystopic Vision of New Life Forms Emerging from Great Pacific Garbage Patch"] ''Calit 2'', Retrieved 27 November 2017.</ref>
In May 2014, ''An Ecosystem of Excess'' was also published as a book by Argobooks.
== Images ==
<gallery mode=packed> Transchromic Eggs by Pinar Yoldas.jpg|"Transchromatic Eggs" which are laid by marine birds on the ocean floor where plastic sinks. Plastic Balloon Turtle by Pinar Yoldas.jpg|"Plastic Baloon Turtle" that evolved to develop an elastomer back. Plastic Soup Morning Recipe by Pinar Yoldas.jpg|"Plastic Soup Morning Recipe" The Plastisphere Insects by Pinar Yoldas.jpg|"The Plastisphere Insects" Plastic sensing organs by Pinar Yoldas.jpg|Plastic sensing organs of Ecosystem of Excess. </gallery>

revision.text:
{{About|an artist collective website|the commercial art-dealing website|Artnet|the lighting industry control system|Art-Net}} [[Image:Abstract.gif|right|thumb|The oil painting ''Earth and Sky'' has greeted visitors to '''Art.Net''' since June, 1994]] '''Art.Net''' is a [[non-profit]] {{citation needed|date=June 2008}} web-based [[artist collective]] of more than 450 [[artist]]s, [[poet]]s, [[musician]]s, [[Painting|painter]]s, [[Sculpture|sculptor]]s, [[animator]]s, [[hacker artist]]s, and other creative people from around the world, aimed at helping artists share their works on the [[World Wide Web]]. Also known as '''Art on the Net,''' the site was established in June, 1994 with a manifesto and statement of purpose as an [[Internet art]] project site and [[Art gallery#Online galleries|online art gallery]].
[[Artist]]s create and maintain studio web spaces on the site and gallery pages where they show their works and share information about themselves. Artists are also encouraged to collaborate and to help each other promote and improve their art. They can learn how to [[curate]] and show their art work via the web. Several member artists also teach art in their studio spaces located on Art.Net.<ref>[http://art.net/studios/visual/Rebecca/LifeDrawing1.html ''Life Drawing Lesson I, Gesture - The Foundation of Figurative Art''] by Rebecca Alzofon accessed on 13 October 2006</ref><ref>[http://art.net/thegallery/Maurel_Room/collab.html Master Printer, Sheila Marbain demonstrates the execution of creating an encaustic monoprint] in an [http://www.art.net/ Art.Net Gallery Room], accessed on 13 October 2006</ref><ref>[http://art.net/thegallery/Maurel_Room/maurel.html ''Silk Monoprinting''] by Sheila Marbain accessed on 13 October 2006</ref> Art.Net is open to new artists and new areas. [http://www.art.net/join/ New artists are invited to join and submit their work for display.] The site provides and supports a variety of online art resources.<ref name="AwardsReceived">[http://art.net/Links/Artref/artref.html Awards Received] accessed on 13 October 2006</ref>
Art.Net is owned and operated by the member artists, and has been active in defending [[Freedom of speech|free speech]] on the [[Internet]]. With the help of the [[American Civil Liberties Union]] (ACLU), Art.Net has been involved in many court cases defending freedom of speech on the Internet. In each case, members were asked to testify in court about how laws censoring content on the Internet prevented the sharing of art due to fear of prosecution. There have been four such cases, in four different states. Each was successful in bringing injunctions against laws, preventing their enforcement. This happened during the time that each state was trying to create local [[Communications Decency Act]] (CDA) laws for their local states.<ref name="Fahrenheit451.2">[https://www.aclu.org/privacy/speech/15145pub20020317.html "Fahrenheit 451.2: Is Cyberspace Burning?" ACLU (2002)] accessed on 13 October 2006</ref>
The website does not censor the artists or their works posted on the site; artists are requested to share their art in a non-commercial way. Artists retain all rights to their works shown on Art.Net. The site typically receives more than 65,000 page views per day from more than 14,000 unique visitors. It has won several awards.<ref name="AwardsReceived"/>
==Protector of the arts and artists==
In the autumn of 1994, Art.Net suffered its first site break-in by the well known [[white hat (computer security)|black hat and cracker]], [[Kevin Mitnick]]. This break-in was the beginning of Mitnick's downfall.{{Citation needed|date=August 2007}} Art.Net's webmaster requested the help of a master [[Hacker (computer security)|hacker]], [[Tsutomu Shimomura]], to deal with the cracker. The break-in was discovered "while in process" and Art.Net immediately responded by turning off all Internet services except for web access via httpd.
In the fall of 1995, Art.Net executed one of the first known reversed Web [[Denial-of-service attack|"Denial of Service" (aka DOS) attacks]].{{citation needed|date=August 2007}} A porn site had linked to one image of an Art.Net member artist's art on Art.Net without the artist's permission. When the artist noticed that the file was being accessed more than usual (several thousand times a day), she reported the strange event to the Art.Net site webmaster. The art image file was moved to another filename and by way of the [[Apache HTTP Server|Apache webserver]] running on Art.Net, accesses to the original file name were redirected back to the offending website's sendmail port. The offending machine went down in a few minutes due to the overload of sendmail connections to their site. A few days later the offending link to the art was removed from the porn site.
==Selected historical milestones== '''June, 1994''' - established.
'''February, 1996''' - joined in the [[Black World Wide Web protest]] from February 8 until February 24 to protest the signing of the telecommunications bill that included the CDA by Bill Clinton on February 8, 1996 as part of the [[Blue Ribbon Online Free Speech Campaign]]. Art.Net continued showing the Blue Ribbon on site entrance page to show support of freedom of speech on the Internet.
'''June, 1996''' - new link submission form<ref>[http://www.art.net/links/linksform.html Link Submission Form] accessed on 13 October 2006</ref> was added on the site.
'''March, 1997''' - joined in the lawsuit ''[[American Library Association|ALA]] v. Pataki'' as a plaintiff to challenge [[New York (state)|New York]]'s Internet censorship law.<ref>[https://www.aclu.org/privacy/speech/15510res19970620.html ''ALA v. Pataki''] accessed on 13 October 2006</ref> Art.Net was placed in jeopardy to help defend freedom of speech on the Internet by joining this case. If it had lost, there would have been a strong chance that the site must shut down because of censorship laws. Represented by the ACLU, the case was won for the plaintiffs Art.Net and many others, and a preliminary injunction against New York's censorship law, preserving freedom of speech on the Internet, was issued.
'''June, 1998''' - joined in the lawsuit ''ACLU v. Johnson'' as a plaintiff to challenge [[New Mexico]]'s online censorship law.<ref>[https://www.aclu.org/privacy/speech/15687res19980627.html ''ACLU v. Johnson''] accessed on 13 October 2006</ref> This was an important case because even though the ACLU won,<ref>[https://www.aclu.org/privacy/speech/15530lgl19980528.html Preliminary Injunction ''ACLU v. Johnson''] accessed on 13 October 2006</ref> the case was appealed by New Mexico.<ref>[https://www.aclu.org/privacy/speech/15091prs19990920.html Appeal of ''ACLU v. Johnson''] accessed on 13 October 2006</ref> The appeals court upheld the ruling, so now this case is a federal precedent, supporting the freedom of speech on the Internet for all U.S. citizens.
'''June 1999''' - joined as a plaintiff in ''Cyberspace v. Engler'', with the ACLU, challenging Michigan's cyber-censorship law, citing the [[United States Constitution|US Constitution]]'s [[Commerce Clause|commerce clause]] and free speech rights.<ref>[https://www.aclu.org/privacy/speech/14940prs19990623.html ''Cyberspace v. Engler''] accessed on 13 October 2006</ref> The court ruled in favor of the plaintiffs, again upholding the right of free speech on the Internet.
'''March 2002''' - in the article, ''Fahrenheit 451.2: Is Cyberspace Burning?'',<ref name="Fahrenheit451.2"/> the Internet is shown to deserve the same high level of free speech protection afforded to books and other printed matter. Art.Net is shown as an example of why self-rating is burdensome, unwieldy, and costly for websites to implement.
==See also== <!-- Please keep entries in alphabetical order & add a short description [[WP:SEEALSO]] --> {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| * [[DeviantArt]] * [[Hacker artist]] * [[SITO]] * [[Women artists]] (Art.Net was founded by, & many members are, women artists.) }} <!-- please keep entries in alphabetical order -->
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * http://www.art.net/

revision.comment: Fixed a typo found with [[Wikipedia:Typo_Team/moss]].
revision.text:
The oldest undisputed examples of [[figurative art]] are known from [[Aurignacian|Europe]] and from [[Sulawesi]], Indonesia, dated about 35,000 years old ([[Art of the Upper Paleolithic]]).<ref name=Aubert2014>M. Aubert et al., "Pleistocene cave art from Sulawesi, Indonesia", ''Nature'' volume 514, pages 223–227 (09 October 2014). "using uranium-series dating of coralloid speleothems directly associated with 12 human hand stencils and two figurative animal depictions from seven cave sites in the Maros karsts of Sulawesi, we show that rock art traditions on this Indonesian island are at least compatible in age with the oldest European art. The earliest dated image from Maros, with a minimum age of 39.9 kyr, is now the oldest known hand stencil in the world. In addition, a painting of a babirusa (‘pig-deer’) made at least 35.4 kyr ago is among the earliest dated figurative depictions worldwide, if not the earliest one. Among the implications, it can now be demonstrated that humans were producing rock art by ∼40 kyr ago at opposite ends of the Pleistocene Eurasian world."</ref> Together with [[Paleolithic religion|religion]] and other [[cultural universal]]s of contemporary human societies, the emergence of [[figurative art]] is a necessary attribute of full [[behavioral modernity]].
There are, however, some examples of non-figurative designs which somewhat predate the Upper Paleolithic, beginning about 70,000 years ago ([[Marine Isotope Stage 4|MIS 4]]). These include the earliest of the [[Franco-Cantabrian region|Iberian cave paintings]], including a [[hand stencil]] at the [[Cave of Maltravieso]], a simple linear design, and red paint applied to [[speleothem]]s, dated to at least 64,000 years ago and as such attributable to [[Neanderthal]]s.<ref name=Hoffmann2018>{{cite journal |author1=D. L. Hoffmann |author2=C. D. Standish |author3=M. García-Diez |author4=P. B. Pettitt |author5=J. A. Milton |author6=J. Zilhão |author7=J. J. Alcolea-González |author8=P. Cantalejo-Duarte |author9=H. Collado |author10=R. de Balbín |author11=M. Lorblanchet |author12=J. Ramos-Muñoz |author13=G.-Ch. Weniger |author14=A. W. G. Pike |year=2018 |title=U-Th dating of carbonate crusts reveals Neandertal origin of Iberian cave art |journal=Science |volume=359 |issue=6378 |pages=912–915 |doi=10.1126/science.aap7778}} "we present dating results for three sites in Spain that show that cave art emerged in Iberia substantially earlier than previously thought. Uranium-thorium (U-Th) dates on carbonate crusts overlying paintings provide minimum ages for a red linear motif in La Pasiega (Cantabria), a hand stencil in Maltravieso (Extremadura), and red-painted speleothems in Ardales (Andalucía). Collectively, these results show that cave art in Iberia is older than 64.8 thousand years (ka). This cave art is the earliest dated so far and predates, by at least 20 ka, the arrival of modern humans in Europe, which implies Neandertal authorship."</ref> Similarly, the [[Blombos Cave]] of [[South Africa]] yielded some stones with engraved grid or cross-hatch patterns, dated to some 70,000 years ago.
In September 2018, scientists reported the discovery of the earliest known drawing by ''[[Homo sapiens]]'', which is estimated to be 73,000 years old, much earlier than the 43,000 years old artifacts understood to be the earliest known modern human drawings found previously.<ref name="NYT-20180912" />
==Europe== {{see|Neanderthal behavior#Claims of art and adornment}} [[File:Acheuleanhandaxes.jpg|right|thumb|150px|Acheulean hand-axes from [[Kent]]. The types shown are (clockwise from top) cordate, ficron and ovate.]] [[Uranium-thorium dating]] of painted designs in the caves of [[La Pasiega]] ([[Cantabria]]), a hand stencil in [[Cave of Maltravieso|Maltravieso]] ([[Extremadura]]), and red-painted speleothems in [[Ardales]] ([[Andalusia]]) yielded an age of more than 64,800 years, predating the previously oldest known art by at least 20,000 years.<ref name=Hoffmann2018/>
The [[Mask of La Roche-Cotard]] has also been argued as being evidence of Neanderthal figurative art, although in a period post-dating their [[Neanderthal Cro-Magnon interaction|contact with ''Homo sapiens'']]. The "[[Divje Babe flute]]" had controversially been claimed as a Neanderthal musical instrument; other archaeologists have claimed a Cro-Magnon origin of the artefact. A number of rival archaeologists maintain an alternative hypothesis that the perfectly circular, spaced, and aligned holes were bite marks of carnivores. The main argument in support of their alternative hypothesis is fundamentally circular in its reasoning: that the artefact which appears to be a flute of Neanderthal origin cannot be a flute of Neanderthal origin because Neanderthals did not have music, according to them.
==Southern Africa== In 2002 in [[Blombos cave]], situated in [[South Africa]], [[ochre]] stones were discovered engraved with grid or cross-hatch patterns, dated to some 70,000 years ago. This suggested to some researchers that [[early Homo sapiens|early ''Homo sapiens'']] were capable of abstraction and production of abstract art or symbolic art. Also discovered at the Blombos cave were shell beads, also dating to c. 70,000 years ago.<ref name=" Watts 2009">Watts, Ian (2009) Red ochre, body painting, and language: interpreting the Blombos ochre. In Botha, Rudolf P. & Knight, Chris (Eds.) The cradle of language. Oxford ; New York, Oxford University Press.</ref> Engraved ochre has also been reported from other Middle Stone Age sites, such as Klein Kliphuis,<ref name=" Mackay and Welz 2008">Mackay, Alex & Welz, Aara (2008) Engraved ochre from a Middle Stone Age context at Klein Kliphuis in the Western Cape of South Africa. Journal of Archaeological Science, 35, 1521–1532.</ref> [[Wonderwerk Cave]]<ref name=" Chazan & Horwitz 2009">Chazan, Michael & Horwitz, Liora Kolska (2009) Milestones in the development of symbolic behaviour: a case study from Wonderwerk Cave, South Africa. World Archaeology, 41, 521-539.</ref> and [[Klasies River Caves|Klasies River Cave 1]].<ref name="d’Errico et al. 2012">d’Errico, Francesco, García Moreno, Renata & Rifkin, Riaan F. (2012) Technological, elemental and colorimetric analysis of an engraved ochre fragment from the Middle Stone Age levels of Klasies River Cave 1, South Africa. Journal of Archaeological Science, 39, 942-952.</ref> Arguably, these engraved pieces of ochre represent – together with the engraved ostrich egg shells from [[Diepkloof Rock Shelter|Diepkloof]]<ref name="Texier 2010">Texier, Pierre-Jean, et al. (2010) A Howiesons Poort tradition of engraving ostrich eggshell containers dated to 60,000 years ago at Diepkloof Rock Shelter, South Africa. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 107, 6180-6185.</ref><ref name="Texier 2013">Texier, Pierre-Jean, et al. The context, form and significance of the MSA engraved ostrich eggshell collection from Diepkloof Rock Shelter, Western Cape, South Africa. Journal of Archaeological Science.</ref> – the earliest forms of abstract representation and conventional design tradition hitherto recorded. The interpretation of the hatching patterns as "symbolic" has been challenged, and several purely functional explanations of the objects have been proposed, e.g. as an ingredient in mastic, skin protection against sun or insects, as soft-hammers for delicate knapping, as a hide preservative or as medicine.<ref name=" Lombard 2006 hafting">Lombard, M. (2006) Direct evidence for the use of ochre in the hafting technology of Middle Stone Age tools from Sibudu Cave. Southern African Humanities, 18, 57–67. Lombard, M. (2007) The gripping nature of ochre: The association of ochre with Howiesons Poort adhesives and Later Stone Age mastics from South Africa. Journal of Human Evolution, 53, 406-419.</ref><ref name="Wadley et al. 2009">Wadley, Lyn, Hodgskiss, Tamaryn & Grant, Michael (2009) Implications for complex cognition from the hafting of tools with compound adhesives in the Middle Stone Age, South Africa. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.</ref><ref name="Wadley 2010">Wadley, Lyn (2010) Compound-Adhesive Manufacture as a Behavioral Proxy for Complex Cognition in the Middle Stone Age. Current Anthropology, 51, S111-S119.</ref><ref name="Rifkin 2012">Rifkin, Riaan F. (2012) The symbolic and functional exploitation of ochre during the South African Middle Stone Age. Institute for Human Evolution (IHE). University of the Witwatersrand.</ref>
In September 2018, scientists reported the discovery of the earliest known drawing by ''[[Homo sapiens]]'', which is estimated to be 73,000 years old, much earlier than the 43,000 years old artifacts understood to be the earliest known modern human drawings found previously.<ref name="NYT-20180912">{{cite news |last=St. Fleur |first=Nicholas|title=Oldest Known Drawing by Human Hands Discovered in South African Cave |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/12/science/oldest-drawing-ever-found.html |date=12 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=15 September 2018 }}</ref>
==Claimed Lower Paleolithic art== {{see|Makapansgat pebble}} [[File:Museo de la Evolucion Humana Burgos - Tan Tan and Berekhat Ram Pebbles.jpg|thumb|150px|"[[Venus of Tan-Tan]]" (left) and "[[Venus of Berekhat Ram]]" (replicas)]] Claims of artistic activity, in the form of diagonal etchings made with a sharks tooth, were made in 2014 relating to a 500,000-year-old fossil of a clam found in Java in the 1890s associated with ''[[Homo erectus]]''.<ref>https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg22429983.200-shell-art-made-300000-years-before-humans-evolved.html#.VISuEibfWnM</ref>
''Homo erectus'' had long before produced seemingly aimless patterns on artifacts such as is those found at [[Bilzingsleben (Paleolithic site)|Bilzingsleben]] in [[Thuringia]]. Some have attempted to interpret these as a precursor to art, allegedly revealing the intent of the maker to decorate and fashion. The symmetry and attention given to the shape of a tool has led authors to controversially argue [[Acheulean]] [[hand axe]]s as artistic expressions.
There are several other claims of Lower Paleolithic art, namely the "[[Venus of Tan-Tan]]" (before 300 kya)<ref name="Chase145">{{cite book|title=The Emergence of Culture: The Evolution of a Uniquely Human Way of Life|first=Philip G|last=Chase|publisher=Birkhäuser|year=2005|ref=Chase|isbn=978-0-387-30512-7}}, pp. 145-146</ref> and the "[[Venus of Berekhat Ram]]" (250 kya). Both of these may be natural rock formations with an incidental likeness to the human form, but some scholars have suggested that they exhibit traces of pigments or carving intended to further accentuate the human-like form.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}}
==See also== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Behavioral modernity]] * [[List of Stone Age art]] * [[Origin of language]] * [[Origin of music]] * [[Prehistoric art]] * [[Prehistoric religion]] * [[Upper Paleolithic art]] {{div col end}}
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Prehistoric technology|state=expanded}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Art Of The Middle Paleolithic}} [[Category:Middle Stone Age]] [[Category:Prehistoric art|Middle Paleolithic]]

revision.text:
{{Italic title}} {{Infobox book | <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Novels or Wikipedia:WikiProject_Books --> | name = Becoming Jane Austen | image = | caption = | cover_artist = | alt = | author = [[Jon Hunter Spence]] | country = | language = English | genre = | publisher = [[Continuum International Publishing Group]] | release_date = 2003 | media_type = | oclc = | isbn = | pages = }} '''''Becoming Jane Austen''''' was researched and written by the Jane Austen scholar [[Jon Hunter Spence]]. It chronicles a demi-biographical version of Austen's early biography based on Spence's interpretation of the novel ''Pride and Prejudice'' as possibly being modeled on Austen's real life, although Austen herself does not make this claim for her novel.
''Becoming Jane Austen'' was first published in hardcover by [[Continuum International Publishing Group|Hambledon Continuum]] in 2003. It chronicles the early life of [[Jane Austen]], the encounters and the developing relationship between Austen and [[Tom Lefroy]], based on letters sent by Jane Austen to her sister Cassandra. The book was used as the basis for the film ''[[Becoming Jane]]'', which was released in January 2007 (Sydney). Jon Spence was a historical consultant for the film.
A review of the book by the Jane Austen Society of North America states that, "Jon Spence’s ''Becoming Jane Austen'' is one of the best half-dozen books published on Austen in the last quarter century, at least. It is a remarkably learned book written in a remarkably lucid style and a joy to read. The research is so substantial, wide-ranging, and detailed that any conjecture Spence builds on it has the feel of bedrock itself. His interpretation of Jane Austen’s character and personality as well as of her fiction impresses the reader with his long and intimate acquaintance with the writer and her works."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jasna.org/bookrev/br193p23.html |title=Spence, Becoming Jane Austen |publisher=Jasna.org |date= |accessdate=2012-02-13}}</ref>
A paperback edition of the book was published by Continuum on 14 June 2007<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/1847250467/ |title=Becoming Jane Austen (9781847250469): Jon Spence: Books |publisher=Amazon.com |date= |accessdate=2012-02-13}}</ref>
The Austen-Lefroy relationship was also used as the basis for ''Jane and Tom: The Real Pride and Prejudice'', a radio play by Elizabeth Lewis. It was first broadcast on 1 June 2007, starring [[Jasmine Hyde]] as Austen and [[Andrew Scott (actor)|Andrew Scott]] as Lefroy, along with [[Penny Downie]] as Mrs Austen, [[Jane Whittenshaw]] as Mrs Lefroy, Rachel Atkins as [[Anne Lefroy]], Lynne Seamore as [[Cassandra Austen]], [[Keiron Self]] as [[John Warren (Austen family friend)|John Warren]], and Manon Edwards as Ellen, and directed by Celia De Wolff.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b007llmb |title=BBC Radio 4 - Afternoon Drama, Jane and Tom: The Real Pride and Prejudice |publisher=BBC |date=1 June 2007|accessdate=2013-05-04}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox film | name = Birds of Paradise | image = Birds of Paradise (2008 film).jpg | caption = Film poster | director = [[Roman Balayan]] | producer = Oleg Kokhan | writer = [[Rustam Ibragimbekov]] | starring = [[Oksana Akinshina]] | music = Vadim Khrapachiv | cinematography = Bogdan Verzhbitsky | editing = | distributor = | released = {{Film date|2008|6||Moscow}} | runtime = 94 minutes | country = Ukraine | language = Russian
Ukrainian | budget = }} '''''Birds of Paradise''''' ({{lang-uk|Райські птахи}}; {{lang-ru|Райские птицы}}, [[Transliteration|translit.]] Rayskie ptitsy) is a 2008 Ukrainian [[drama film]] directed by [[Roman Balayan]]. It was entered into the [[30th Moscow International Film Festival]].{{cite web|url=http://www.moscowfilmfestival.ru/miff34/eng/archives/?year=2008 |title=30th Moscow International Film Festival (2008) |accessdate=2 June 2013 |work=MIFF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130421050837/http://www.moscowfilmfestival.ru/miff34/eng/archives/?year=2008 |archivedate=21 April 2013 |df=dmy }} ==Cast== * [[Oksana Akinshina]] * [[Andriy Kuzychiev]] * [[Oleg Yankovskiy]] * [[Yehor Pazenko]] * [[Serhiy Romaniuk]] * [[Serhiy Siplivy]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|1327600|Birds of Paradise}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|birds-of-paradise|Birds of Paradise}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Birds Of Paradise}} [[Category:2008 films]] [[Category:2000s drama films]] [[Category:Ukrainian films]] [[Category:Ukrainian-language films]] [[Category:Russian-language films]] [[Category:Films directed by Roman Balayan]] {{Ukraine-film-stub}} {{2000s-drama-film-stub}}

page.title: Coat of arms of Puerto Rico

revision.comment: /* History */ Including alternate view among historians that the "I" is actually a "J" in honor of the Queen under which the Coat of Arms was granted.
revision.text:
{{Infobox coat of arms |name = Coat of Arms of Puerto Rico |image = Coat_of_arms_of_the_Commonwealth_of_Puerto_Rico.svg |image_width = 170 |middle = Coat of arms of the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico (variant).svg |middle_width = 170 |middle_caption = Variant |lesser = |lesser_width = |lesser_caption = |image2 = |image2_width = |image2_caption = |image3 = |image3_width = |image3_caption = |armiger = [[Commonwealth of Puerto Rico]] |year_adopted = 1976 (1511 & 1905) |crest = |torse = |shield = |supporters = |compartment = |motto = '''Joannes Est Nomen Ejus''', [[Latin]] "John is his name". |orders = |other_elements = |earlier_versions = |use = }} The '''coat of arms of [[Puerto Rico]]''' was first granted by the [[Spanish monarchy|Spanish Crown]] in 1511, making it the oldest heraldic achievement still currently in use in the Americas.<ref name="New York Daily News, June 3, 2008">[http://www.nydailynews.com/latino/2008/06/04/2008-06-04_have_a_puerto_rican_question_ask_el_bori.html?page=1 ''New York Daily News'', June 3, 2008.]</ref> The territory was ceded by Spain to the United States in accordance to the peace treaty that ended the [[Spanish–American War]] in 1899, after which two interim arms were adopted briefly. A law was passed in 1905 that re-established the historical armorial bearings as the arms of the territory; after numerous investigations and amendments, the current version was adopted in 1976.
==History== [[File:Columbus Taking Possession.jpg|thumb|250px|left|[[Christopher Columbus]] arriving in the [[New World]] carrying a banner with the initials of [[Ferdinand II of Aragon|Ferdinand II]] and [[Isabella I of Castile|Isabella I]].]] The major symbolism of the coat of arms relates to the dominance of Spain, the strong Roman Catholic influence in the region, and the integrity of Puerto Rico as a colony of Spain. There have been different variations of the coat of arms changing throughout Puerto Rico's history. The current version was officially re-adopted by the Commonwealth government of [[Puerto Rico]] on 3 June 1976.
On the shield: * The green background represents the island's vegetation. The [[Lamb of God]] and cross flag on the shield are symbols traditionally associated with [[St. John the Baptist]], patron of the island. The book with the seven seals on which the lamb sits represents symbolism from the [[Book of Revelation]], generally attributed to [[St. John the Apostle]]. * The border is made up of 16 different elements: castles and lions to represent the [[Kingdom of Castile]] and the [[Kingdom of León]], a flag with the arms of the [[Crown of Castile]] and León, and The Cross of [[Jerusalem]] to stand for the [[Kingdom of Jerusalem]], whose succession rights passed to the [[Kingdom of Sicily]], and henceforth to the [[Spanish Crown]]. * The gold-crowned '''''[[F]]''''' and the [[arrow]]s ({{lang-es|flechas}}) represent [[Ferdinand II of Aragon|'''F'''erdinand II of Aragon]], while the '''''[[Y]]''''' and the [[yoke]] ({{lang-es|yugo}}) represent Ysabel, i.e., [[Isabella I of Castile|'''I'''sabella I of Castile]] who were the [[Catholic monarchs]] when Puerto Rico was discovered.<ref> [http://www.gobierno.pr/GPRPortal/Inicio/PuertoRico/Simbolo] s/Escudo.htm Official Puerto Ricao Government website.]</ref> It is said, that the "I" on the shield, was in fact a "J" representing Queen "Joanna", commonly known as "Juana La Loca", daughter, and successor of Queen Isabella after she allegedly became mentally ill after the death of her husband, and in whose name her father, as regent of Spain granted the coat of arms to the Spanish territory of San Juan, as Puerto Rico was then known. * The [[Latin]] motto, "JOANNES EST NOMEN EJUS" (a quotation from the [[Vulgate]] of [[Gospel of Luke|Luke]] 1:63), means "John is his name", referring to [[St. John the Baptist]] or San Juan Bautista, the original name of the island.<ref>Grabowski, John F. (1992). ''U.S. Territories and Possessions (State Report Series)''. Chelsea House Pub. Page 7. {{ISBN|9780791010532}}.</ref>
{{Infobox coat of arms |name = Great Seal of Puerto Rico |image = Great Seal of the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico.svg |image_width = 200 |middle = |middle_width = |middle_caption = |lesser = |lesser_width = |lesser_caption = |image2 = |image2_width = |image2_caption = |image3 = |image3_width = |image3_caption = |armiger = Commonwealth of Puerto Rico |year_adopted = |crest = |torse = |shield = |supporters = |compartment = |motto = '''Joannes Est Nomen Ejus''', [[Latin]] "John is his name". |orders = |other_elements = |earlier_versions = |use = }}
==Great Seal== All of the states and territories of the United States employ a seal to authenticate and ratify documents and accordingly a seal of Puerto Rico exists, but the traditional coat of arms is used as the main emblem of the commonwealth. The seal has most of the elements of the coat of arms, but the religious elements have been stripped away in accordance with the [[Separation of church and state in the United States]]. In the seal, the lamb, which no longer has a halo, carries a white banner instead of one with a red cross. The lamb's staff does not have the cross mounted on top. The book the lamb sits on does not have the seals of the Book of Revelation. The first Governors used the seal as their emblem but in recent years the usage of the seal has been limited to being the official emblem used to represent Puerto Rico on its legal documents when they are sealed.
==Seal of the Governor== The Seal of the [[Governor of Puerto Rico|Governor]] is the official symbol of the executive head of Puerto Rico. It follows the design used by the [[Seal of the President of the United States]]. There are several variants of the Governor's Seal in use.
<gallery> File:Seal of the Governor of Puerto Rico.svg|[[Seals of the Governors of the U.S. States|Seal]] of the [[Governor of Puerto Rico]] File:Seal of the Governor of Puerto Rico (Variant).svg|A variant of the Governor's seal File:Seal of the Governor-Elect of Puerto Rico.svg|Seal of the Governor Elect </gallery>
==Seals of the government of Puerto Rico== There are several seals of the different sections of the [[Government of Puerto Rico|Puerto Rican government]].
<gallery> File:Seal of the Secretary of State of Puerto Rico.svg|Seal of the [[Secretary of State of Puerto Rico|Secretary of State]] of Puerto Rico File:Seal of Puerto Rico Legislature.svg|Seal of the [[Legislative Assembly of Puerto Rico|Legislative Assembly]] of Puerto Rico File:Seal of Puerto Rico House of Representatives.svg|Seal of the [[House of Representatives of Puerto Rico|House of Representatives]] of Puerto Rico File:Seal of Puerto Rico Senate.svg|Seal of the [[Senate of Puerto Rico|Senate]] of Puerto Rico File:Seal of Puerto Rico Senate (Variant).svg|A variant of the seal of the Senate </gallery>
==See also== {{Portal|Puerto Rico|Heraldry|Puerto Rico/Did you know-Puerto Rico?}} * [[Puerto Rico]] * [[Castile and Leon]] * [[Spanish heraldry]] * [[Coat of arms]] * [[Heraldry]] * [[Coat of Arms of the U.S. States|Coats of arms of the U.S. states]] * [[Seals of the U.S. states]] {{Clear}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100123025742/http://www.gobierno.pr/GPRPortal/Inicio/PuertoRico/Simbolos/Escudo.htm Coat of Arms information from the Government of Puerto Rico]
==References== {{Reflist|1}} {{Puerto Rico topics}} {{US state seals}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Coat Of Arms Of Puerto Rico}} [[Category:Seals of places in the United States|Puerto Rico]] [[Category:American coats of arms|Puerto Rico]] [[Category:National symbols of Puerto Rico]] [[Category:National coats of arms|Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Seals of country subdivisions|Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Coats of arms with lions|Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Coats of arms with flags|Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Coats of arms with lambs of God|Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Coats of arms with crowns|Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Coats of arms with crosses|Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Coats of arms with buildings|Puerto Rico]]
