{{Infobox company | name = Half Price Books, Records, Magazines, Inc. | logo = File:Half_Price_Books_logo.png | type = | logo_caption = "We buy anything printed or recorded except yesterday's newspaper". | foundation = 1972 | location = [[Dallas, Texas]] | key_people = Sharon Anderson Wright, CEO | industry = [[Retail|Retail (Specialty)]] | num_employees = | num_locations = 127 (2016)<ref name="Cobb">{{cite news|last1=Stafford|first1=Leon|title=Cobb Readers Rejoice {{en dash}} New Bookstore Coming|url=http://www.ajc.com/business/cobb-readers-rejoice-new-bookstore-coming/EXNB3IE27CK18L1oTXkyUI/|accessdate=25 July 2017|newspaper=[[The Atlanta Journal-Constitution]]|date=May 25, 2016}}</ref> | products = [[Books]], [[Gramophone record|Record]]s, [[CD]]s, [[DVD]]s, [[Magazines]], [[Video Game]]s | subsid = | homepage = [http://www.hpb.com hpb.com] | revenue = }}
'''Half Price Books, Records, Magazines, Incorporated''' is the largest family-owned chain of new and used [[bookstore]]s in the [[United States]]. The company’s original motto is "We buy and sell anything printed or recorded except yesterday's newspaper", and many of the used books, music, and movies for sale in each location are purchased from local residents. The corporate office is located in the flagship [[Texas State Highway Loop 12|Northwest Highway]] location in [[Dallas, Texas]]. Half Price Books now operates more than 127 stores (including outlets) in 17 states.<ref name="Cobb" /><ref>{{cite web|title=Our Stores|url=https://www.hpb.com/stores/|publisher=Half Price Books|accessdate=July 25, 2017}}</ref>
==History== [[File:HPB Dallas NWH 20100329.jpg|thumb|Entrance to the Half Price Books Northwest Highway, the corporate headquarters, on E. Northwest Highway in [[Dallas, Texas]]]] [[File:Half Price Books, Berkeley.JPG|thumb|Half Price Books in [[Berkeley, California]]]]
Founders Ken Gjemre and Pat Anderson opened the first store in 1972 in a former [[laundromat]] in Dallas, Texas, filling the shelves with 2,000 books out of their personal libraries.<ref>{{cite news|title=Obituaries: Passings Ken Gjemre, 81; Left Corporate Career to Found Bookstore Chain|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2002/jun/01/local/me-passing1.3|accessdate=25 July 2017|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=June 1, 2002}}</ref> Pat Anderson’s daughter, Sharon Anderson Wright, is the company’s current President and [[CEO]]. In 2009, Sharon's sister Ellen O'Neal stepped up to the position of Chairperson of the Board in order to become more involved with the family business.
==Philanthropy== The Half Price Books original mission statement includes the promise to "promote [[literacy]] and be kind to the environment."<ref name="Social">{{cite news|last1=Lasica|first1=JD|title=Where to Find Nonprofit, Independent & Progressive Booksellers|url=http://www.socialbrite.org/tag/half-price-books/|accessdate=July 25, 2017|publisher=SocialBrite}}</ref> Teachers and librarians, for example, are offered a year-round 10% discount on purchases.<ref name=Social /> Each year, every Half Price Books store holds a book drive to collect new or gently used children's books, building "Half Pint Libraries" at non-profit organizations and schools in the communities it serves.<ref>{{cite web|title=Half Pint Library|url=http://b.hpb.com/half-pint-library-book-drive/|publisher=Half Price Books|accessdate=February 21, 2018}}</ref>
The company has promoted [[recycling]] and reusing, and the sound management of paper, energy and water resources. In 2008, Half Price Books launched a formal environmental education initiative called “B(eco)me Green” to help spread knowledge about the health of the environment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.becomegreen.org|website=b(eco)me green|title=Become Green|accessdate=February 21, 2018}}</ref>
In addition, the chain donates millions of books and its overstock inventory to non-profit organizations around the world such as [[Feed the Children]] and [[American Red Cross]]. It also gives some of its books to [[Better World Books]], a for-profit on-line bookseller.
==Publishing== Half Price Books publishes some of the books it sells, inexpensively reprinting non-copyrighted titles or acquiring the U.S. or English language rights from another publisher. Half Price Books reprints these titles under its publishing arm, Hackberry Press.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.trademarkia.com/hackberry-press-75664818.html|title=Hackberry Press {{en dash}} Trademark|publisher=Trademarkia|accessdate=February 21, 2018}}</ref>
Among Hackberry Press titles is the Half Price Books children's storybook series ''[[Say Good Night to Illiteracy]]'', with 13 editions in print. All proceeds from the series benefit family [[literacy]] organizations such as Reach Out and Read and the National Center for Family Literacy.
The company is a strong proponent of the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] freedom of speech and Americans’ right to knowledge and the expression of ideas. Its website “deletecensorship.org” supports imaginative and courageous books, including those that address controversial topics and have been censored or banned.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.deletecensorship.org|website=DeleteCensorship|title=Delete Censorship|accessdate=February 21, 2018}}</ref>
==Wholesale== The wholesale division of Half Price Books is Texas Bookman, also headquartered in Dallas.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.manta.com/c/mmj4mfz/texas-bookman|title=Texas Bookman|accessdate=February 21, 2018|publisher=Manta}}</ref> Texas Bookman sells trade and scholarly remainders at discount prices to wholesale buyers around the world.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Portal|Dallas-Fort Worth|Companies}} *{{Official website|http://www.hpb.com}} *[http://www.becomegreen.org BecomeGreen.org] - an environmental initiative by Half Price Books *[http://www.deletecensorship.org DeleteCensorship.org] - a Banned Books Awareness message sponsored by Half Price Books *[http://www.facebook.com/pages/Half-Price-Books/9187496860 Official Facebook Page]
{{Bookstore Chains}}

{{About|the 1999 film|the 1945 film|Gloria Jean}} {{Infobox film | name = I'll Remember April | image_size = | image = I'll Remember April FilmPoster.jpeg | caption = | director = [[Bob Clark]] | producer = [[Paul Colichman]]
[[David Forrest (pseudonym)|David Forrest]]
[[Mark R. Harris]]
[[Mark Headley]]
[[Sam Irvin]] | writer = [[Mark Sanderson]] | narrator = | starring = [[Pat Morita]]
[[Trevor Morgan (actor)|Trevor Morgan]]
[[Pam Dawber]]
[[Haley Joel Osment]]
[[Mark Harmon]] | music = [[Paul Zaza]] | cinematography = Stephen M. Katz | editing = | distributor = [[Regent Releasing|Regent Entertainment]]
[[Pioneer Entertainment]] | released = {{Film date|1999|4|5}} | runtime = 90 min. | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''I'll Remember April''''' is a 1999 American [[family film|family]] [[drama film|drama]] film starring [[Pat Morita]], [[Pam Dawber]], [[Haley Joel Osment]], [[Mark Harmon]] and [[Yuki Tokuhiro]]. It was directed by [[Bob Clark]]. ==Plot== {{Expand section|date=April 2010}} Four children capture a [[Japan]]ese soldier who washes ashore during the [[World War II|Second World War]]. Although the horrors of World War II are far removed from the Pacific Coast community where adolescent Duke Cooper (Trevor Morgan) and his three best chums play soldier, experiment with swearing, and earnestly patrol the beach for Japanese submarines, the realities of the war are about to come crashing down around them. Not when a Japanese soldier, stranded and wounded when his sub quickly dived, washes ashore; his capture by the foursome merely allows for more playtime and thoughts of becoming heroes. It's coming because Duke's older brother is on some island awaiting combat and the black sedans with military tags have already begun rolling through town to deliver their grim announcements. And Duke's Japanese American pal Willie Tanaka (Yuki Tokuhiro), all three feet and 55 pounds of him, has suddenly become a threat to national security, so he, his mother, and grandfather are soon to be shipped away to an internment camp. ==External links== *{{IMDb title|id=0155754|title=I'll Remember April}} *{{rotten-tomatoes|ill_remember_april}} {{Bob Clark}} {{DEFAULTSORT:I'll Remember April (Film)}} [[Category:1999 films]] [[Category:1990s drama films]] [[Category:1990s independent films]] [[Category:1990s war films]] [[Category:American adventure drama films]] [[Category:American children's drama films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American independent films]] [[Category:Anti-war films about World War II]] [[Category:Films scored by Paul Zaza]] [[Category:Films about children]] [[Category:Films about families]] [[Category:Films about friendship]] [[Category:Films about race and ethnicity]] [[Category:Films about racism]] [[Category:Films directed by Bob Clark]] [[Category:World War II films]] [[Category:American children's films]] {{child-film-stub}} {{war-film-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2011}} [[Image:Ifmcasquare.jpg|right|thumb]] The '''International Film Music Critics Association''' ('''IFMCA''') is a professional association for [[music journalism|online, print and radio journalists]] who specialize in writing about [[film score|original film and television music]].
==History and purpose== The IFMCA was founded in the late 1990s as the '''Film Music Critics Jury''' by film music journalist [[Mikael Carlsson]] (now the owner of film music record label [[MovieScore Media]]), and after period of inactivity was re-launched in 2003 under its new title.
Its membership includes 65 journalists from 16 different countries who write for such high-profile film and soundtrack-related publications and websites as [[Film Score Monthly]], [[Filmtracks.com|Filmtracks]], [[SoundtrackNet]], [[Music from the Movies]] and [[UnderScores]], as well as more mainstream publications such as [[Ain't It Cool News]], [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]], ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' and the [[Irish Times]]. Members of the IFMCA have also been involved in writing [[liner notes]] for major film music record labels such as [[Film Score Monthly]], [[Varèse Sarabande]], [[Intrada Records]], La-La Land Records and [[Music Box Records]].
The aim of the group is to promote original film music and the work of film music composers as legitimate artists worthy of recognition from the mainstream film and music media, and to publicize the work of its members in pursuing this aim. To this end, the group maintains a website documenting its activities; operates a central online review interface which provides links to articles, reviews and interviews written by its members; organizes an annual awards event, the IFMCA Awards, celebrating music for films written during the preceding year; and is involved in organizing major international film music festivals, such as those in [[Tenerife International Film Music Festival|Tenerife]],<ref>{{cite web |author=Home |url=http://www.fimucite.com/f4/en/ |title=Tenerife International Film Music Festival |publisher=Fimucite.com |accessdate=11 November 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711002151/http://www.fimucite.com/f4/en/# |archive-date=11 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Úbeda]] in Spain,<ref>[http://festival.bsospirit.com/en/index.php ]{{dead link|date=November 2011}}</ref> [[Kraków]] in Poland,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fmp.org.pl/ |title=Festiwal Muzyki Polskiej |publisher=Fmp.org.pl |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> and the [[World Soundtrack Academy|World Soundtrack Awards]] in [[Ghent]], Belgium.<ref>{{cite web|author=Poland |url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/members/ |title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » Members |publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref>
==IFMCA Awards== The organization is responsible for the annual International Film Music Critics Association Awards, the only awards given to composers by active film music journalists, and which are seen by many as a valuable precursor to the [[Academy Awards]] in the absence of a guild for composers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://incontention.com/2010/01/29/international-film-music-critics-nominees/ |title=International Film Music Critics nominees |publisher=Incontention.com |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> They have been called the "Oscars of film music",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.es/agencias/noticia.asp?noticia=704788 |title=Araujo, premio IFMCA a la banda sonora de videojuegos por "Lords of Shadow" |publisher=Abc.es |date=25 February 2011 |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> have been featured in major daily newspapers in Spain<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elpais.com/articulo/Pantallas/Sinfonias/videojuego/elpepurtv/20110308elpepirtv_1/Tes |title=Sinfonías en el videojuego: Premio internacional para Óscar Araujo por una banda sonora |publisher=Elpais.com |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> and Portugal,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mundoportugues.org/content/1/8810/nuno-malo-eleito-compositor-revelacao-ano-nos-estados-unidos/ |title=Nuno Malo eleito o compositor revelação do ano nos Estados Unidos |publisher=Mundoportugues.org |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> are recognized by major performing rights organizations such as [[ASCAP]] in the United States<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ascap.com/playback/2011/02/Faces_Places/FilmTV/IFMCA_Awards.aspx |title=ASCAP Composers Score at the IFMCA Awards |publisher=Ascap.com |date=1 March 2011 |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> and [[Sociedad General de Autores y Editores|SGAE]] in Europe,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sgae.es/el-compositor-catalan-oscar-araujo-gana-el-premio-a-la-mejor-banda-sonora-2010-para-videojuego-de-la-international-film-music-critics-association/ |title=SGAE: El compositor catalán Óscar Araujo gana el Premio a la Mejor Banda Sonora 2010 para Videojuego de la International Film Music Critics Association |publisher=Sgae.es |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> and most recently have been seen by the video games industry as an important step forward in legitimizing game music as a mainstream creative art form.<ref>{{cite web|last=Kietzmann |first=Ludwig |url=http://www.joystiq.com/2011/02/12/castlevania-lords-of-shadow-soundtrack-nominated-for-2-ifmca/ |title=Castlevania: Lords of Shadow soundtrack nominated for 2 IFMCA awards |publisher=Joystiq.com |date=12 February 2011 |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref>
Composers as varied as [[John Debney]],<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.gsamusic.com/pdf/Debney_John.pdf# |title=Archived copy |access-date=5 March 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606234936/http://www.gsamusic.com/pdf/Debney_John.pdf# |archive-date=6 June 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Alexandre Desplat]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alexandredesplat.net/us/bio-e.htm |title=Alexandre Desplat's biography |publisher=Alexandredesplat.net |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> [[Randy Edelman]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.randyedelman.com/bio/bioNF.htm |title=Bio |publisher=Randy Edelman |accessdate=11 November 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927175242/http://www.randyedelman.com/bio/bioNF.htm# |archive-date=27 September 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[George Fenton]],<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.gsamusic.com/pdf/Fenton_George.pdf# |title=Archived copy |access-date=5 March 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606235217/http://www.gsamusic.com/pdf/Fenton_George.pdf# |archive-date=6 June 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Michael Giacchino]],<ref>http://www.gsamusic.com/pdf/Giacchino_Michael.pdf{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> [[James Newton Howard]]<ref>http://www.gsamusic.com/pdf/Howard_James_Newton.pdf{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> [[Mark Isham]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://isham.com/about/bio/ |title=Mark Isham Music – Bio |publisher=Isham.com |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> [[Andrew Lockington]],<ref>{{cite web|author=<!--Biography --> <!-- 20 September 2010--> |url=http://www.andrewlockington.com/?page_id=25 |title=Composer » Biography |publisher=Andrew Lockington |date=20 September 2010 |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> [[Abel Korzeniowski]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abelkorzeniowski.com/info |title=Info |publisher=Abel Korzeniowski |date=23 October 2010 |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> [[Brian Tyler (composer)|Brian Tyler]],<ref>http://www.gsamusic.com/pdf/Tyler_Brian.pdf{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> [[Fernando Velázquez (composer)|Fernando Velázquez]]<ref>http://www.gsamusic.com/pdf/Velazquez_Fernando.pdf{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> and [[Debbie Wiseman]]<ref>[http://www.debbiewiseman.co.uk/awards.asp ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090817135514/http://www.debbiewiseman.co.uk/awards.asp |date=17 August 2009 }}</ref> highlight their IFMCA Award wins and nominations in their official biographies.
===Major award winners=== *1998 Score of the Year: [[Mulan (1998 film)|Mulan]], by [[Jerry Goldsmith]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/awards-archive/1998-fmcj-awards/ |title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » 1998 FMCJ Awards |publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=24 October 2012}}</ref> *1998 Composer of the Year: [[Jerry Goldsmith]]
*1999 Score of the Year: [[The Mummy (1999 film)|The Mummy]], by [[Jerry Goldsmith]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/awards-archive/1999-fmcj-awards/ |title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » 1999 FMCJ Awards |publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=24 October 2012}}</ref> *1999 Composer of the Year: [[Jerry Goldsmith]]
*2000 - AWARDS NOT GIVEN *2001 - AWARDS NOT GIVEN *2002 - AWARDS NOT GIVEN *2003 - AWARDS NOT GIVEN
*2004 Score of the Year: [[The Incredibles]], by [[Michael Giacchino]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/awards-archive/2004-ifmca-awards/ |title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » 2004 IFMCA Awards |publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> *2004 Composer of the Year: [[Michael Giacchino]]
*2005 Score of the Year: [[Memoirs of a Geisha (film)|Memoirs of a Geisha]], by [[John Williams]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/awards-archive/2005-ifmca-awards/ |title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » 2005 IFMCA Awards |publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> *2005 Composer of the Year: [[John Williams]]
*2006 Score of the Year: [[Lady in the Water]], by [[James Newton Howard]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/awards-archive/2006-ifmca-awards/ |title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » 2006 IFMCA Awards |publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> *2006 Composer of the Year: [[Alexandre Desplat]]
*2007 Score of the Year: [[Atonement (film)|Atonement]], by [[Dario Marianelli]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/awards-archive/2007-ifmca-awards/ |title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » 2007 IFMCA Awards |publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> *2007 Composer of the Year: [[Alexandre Desplat]]
*2008 Score of the Year: [[The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (film)|The Curious Case of Benjamin Button]], by [[Alexandre Desplat]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/2009/02/ifmca-announces-its-2008-winners-for-scoring-excellence/ |title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » IFMCA announces its 2008 winners for scoring excellence |publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |date=19 February 2009 |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> *2008 Composer of the Year: [[Danny Elfman]]
*2009 Score of the Year: [[Up (soundtrack)|Up]], by [[Michael Giacchino]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/2010/03/ifmca-announces-winners-of-2009-awards/ |title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » IFMCA announces winners of 2009 Awards |publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> *2009 Composer of the Year: [[Michael Giacchino]]
*2010 Score of the Year: [[How to Train Your Dragon: Music from the Motion Picture|How to Train Your Dragon]], by [[John Powell (composer)|John Powell]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/2011/02/ifmca-announces-its-2010-winners-for-scoring-excellence/ |title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » IFMCA announces its 2010 Winners for scoring excellence |publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |date=26 October 2011 |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> *2010 Composer of the Year: [[Alexandre Desplat]]
*2011 Score of the Year: [[War Horse (film)|War Horse]], by [[John Williams]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/2012/02/ifmca-winners-2011/|title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » IFMCA Winners 2011|publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=23 February 2012}}</ref> *2011 Composer of the Year: [[John Williams]]
*2012 Score of the Year: [[Life of Pi (film)|Life of Pi]], by [[Mychael Danna]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/2013/02/ifmca-winners-2012/|title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » IFMCA Winners 2012|publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=21 February 2013}}</ref> *2012 Composer of the Year: [[Danny Elfman]]
*2013 Score of the Year: [[Romeo and Juliet (2013 film)|Romeo and Juliet]], by [[Abel Korzeniowski]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/2014/02/ifmca-winners-2013/|title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » IFMCA Winners 2013|publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=20 February 2014}}</ref> *2013 Composer of the Year: [[Abel Korzeniowski]]
*2014 Score of the Year: [[Interstellar (film)|Interstellar]], by [[Hans Zimmer]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/2015/02/ifmca-award-winners-2014//|title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » IFMCA Winners 2014|publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=19 February 2015}}</ref> *2014 Composer of the Year: [[Alexandre Desplat]]
*2015 Score of the Year: [[Star Wars: The Force Awakens]], by [[John Williams]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/2016/02/ifmca-award-winners-2015//|title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » IFMCA Winners 2015|publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=25 February 2016}}</ref> *2015 Composer of the Year: [[Michael Giacchino]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/2016/02/ifmca-award-winners-2015//|title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » IFMCA Winners 2015|publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=25 February 2016}}</ref>
*2016 Score of the Year: [[Arrival (film)|Arrival]], by [[Jóhann Jóhannsson]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/2017/02/ifmca-winners-2016///|title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » IFMCA Winners 2016|publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=24 February 2017}}</ref> *2016 Composer of the Year: [[Michael Giacchino]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/2017/02/ifmca-winners-2016///|title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » IFMCA Winners 2016|publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=24 February 2017}}</ref>
*2017 Score of the Year: [[Phantom Thread]], by [[Jonny Greenwood]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/2018/02/ifmca-award-winners-2017////|title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » IFMCA Winners 2017|publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=24 February 2018}}</ref> *2017 Composer of the Year: [[Alexandre Desplat]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/2018/02/ifmca-award-winners-2017////|title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » IFMCA Winners 2017|publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=24 February 2018}}</ref>

/* Characters */
revision.text:
{{Infobox Lego theme |image=[[File:Lego Fabuland logo.png|200px]] |name=Lego Fabuland |from=1979 |to=1989 |sets=102 |characters=Edward Elephant
Bonnie Bunny
Max Mouse
Mike Monkey
Paulette Poodle }} '''Lego Fabuland''' was a theme and product range of the [[Lego]] construction toy, aimed at young children. Introduced in 1979, the range aimed to fill the gap between [[Lego Duplo|Duplo]] and the standard Lego product ranges. Aimed at both boys and girls, the range encouraged storytelling, and was the first theme to be extended into books, clothing, and a [[claymation]] [[Edward and Friends|TV series]] that aired in the UK and Canada during the 1980s as [[Edward and Friends]]. Each episode was five minutes in length. == Characters == Fabuland sets featured [[anthropomorphic]] animal characters. These pieces were larger than standard Lego [[Minifigures]], but smaller than Duplo figures, and included movable arms, legs and head. Some of the characters appeared in more than one set, and were given names, and sometimes even stories. Recurring characters included Edward Elephant, Bonnie Bunny, Max Mouse, Clive Crocodile, Walter (Wilfred) Walrus, Wally Walrus, Lucy Lamb, Lisa Lamb, Ricky Raccoon, Roger Raccoon, Freddy Fox, Bruno Bear, Bernard Bear, Billy Bear, Perry Panda, Patrick Panda, Bertie Bulldog, Boris Bulldog, Buster Bulldog, Barty Bulldog, Clarke Bulldog, Mike Monkey, Mark Monkey, Gabriel Gorilla (Chester Chimp), Paulette Poodle, Harry Horse, Henry Horse, Catherine Cat, Charlie Cat, Sandy Seagull, Lionel Lion, Legal Beagle, Hannah Hippopotamus, Joe Crow, Marjorie Mouse, Mortimer Mouse, Michael Mouse, Patricia Piglet, Patrick Pig, Percy Pig, Peter Pig, Hugo Hog, Billy Goat, Gertrude Goat, Clara Cow, Doctor Dog, Paul Parrot, Robby Rabbit, Bert Bear and Ernie Elephant. This was the first Lego theme which characters had names. In different countries names of the same characters were different. ==Style== Fabuland had a distinctive friendly style with various animal characters that each had a job or purpose in the town of Fabuland. Fabuland featured special elements that were larger than standard Lego bricks, but were fully compatible with regular Lego. Fabuland used a primary colour scheme and the sets were aimed for children between 4-8 as a transition from Duplo to Lego. Fabuland was unique due to the special elements, such as walls, roof elements, tables, chairs, boats and cars chassis. Larger Sets included buildings with story book like instructions and the theme also had many vehicles and individual characters with accessories. Fabuland is highly sought after today among collectors and there is a large fan base that keeps the theme alive via Lego fan sites. Fabuland was discontinued in 1989 and since then many elements have reappeared in many themes. In 2000, Lego released the [[Lego Mickey Mouse|Mickey Mouse theme]] that contained many Fabuland elements. Fabuland elements have appeared in [[Lego Harry Potter|Harry Potter]], [[Lego Belville|Belville]], [[Lego Castle|Castle]]/Kingdoms, [[Lego Friends|Friends]] and Lego Games and others. The Fabuland line was referenced in the 2014 film ''[[The Lego Movie]]''. ==Sets== ===1979 Sets=== * '''324 Ricky Raccoon on his Scooter ''' ** 2 pieces, 1 minifig * '''325 Percy Pig with his Barrow''' ** 3 pieces, 1 minifig * '''121/328 Michael Mouse and his New Car (Car − Michael Mouse Goes Driving)''' ** 22 pieces, 1 minifig * '''329 Bernard Bear and his Delivery Lorry (Lorry − Bernard Bear Delivers The Goods)''' ** 109 pieces, 1 minifig * '''128/338 Blondi the Pig and Taxi Station (Taxi Station/Patrick Pig is Fabuland's Taxi Man)''' ** 37 pieces, 1 minifig * '''132/341 Catherine Cat's House and Mortimer Mouse (Cottage/House)''' ** 123 pieces, 2 minifig * '''134/344 Service Station with Billy Goat and Mike Monkey''' ** 80 pieces, 2 minifigs * '''137/347 Hospital - Lucy Lamb and Charlie Cat Visit Dr. Dog (Hospital)''' ** 205 pieces, 3 minifigs * '''140/350 Town Hall''' ** 122 pieces, 3 minifigs ===1980 Sets=== * '''3602 Lisa Lamb With Her Pram (Pram − Lisa Lamb Goes Walking)''' ** 3 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3604 Mark Monkey With His Fruit Stall''' ** 3 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3605 Ricky Raccoon and His Scooter''' (same as 324) ** 1 piece, 1 minifig * '''3634 Dustcart − Joe Crow Keeps Fabuland Clean and Tidy (Charlie Crow's Carry-All)''' ** 17 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3665 Harry Horse and Clara Cow's Ice Cream Shoppe (Ice Cream Shop − Harry Horse Helps Clara Cow)''' ** 36 pieces, 2 minifigs ===1981 Sets=== * '''3601 Elton Elephant (Edward Elephant's Garden Table)''' ** 6 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3603 Boris Bulldog and Mailbox (Boris Bulldog Postman)''' ** 5 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3615 Percy Pig''' (same as 325) ** 4 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3628 Perry Panda and Chester Chimp (Window Cleaners)''' ** 3 pieces, 2 minifigs * '''3629 Barney Bear (Bruno Bear's Car/Mechanic's Car)''' ** 16 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3635 Bonnie Bunny's Camper (Mobile Home/House On Wheels)''' ** 25 pieces, 1 minifig ===1982 Sets=== * '''3654 Lisa Lamb's House (The Flower pieces, 2 minifigs * '''3669 Fire Station (The Naughty Raccoon)''' ** 33 pieces, 3 minifigs * '''3672 The Motel (The Cooking Contest)''' ** 60 pieces, 3 minifigs * '''3678 Lionel Lion's Lodge (The Noisy Neighbours)''' ** 123 pieces, 4 minifigs * '''3694/3695 Fabuland Figure Collection''' ** ? pieces, 80 minifigs * '''3701 Charlie Cat the Fisherman (Fisherman)''' ** 2 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3703 Peter Pig the Cook (Cook)''' ** 2 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3704 Marjorie Mouse (Housekeeper)''' ** 2 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3706 Ernie Elephant (Street Sweeper)''' ** 2 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3707 Clara Cow (Gardener)''' ** 2 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3708 Rufus Rabbit (Baker's Boy)''' ** 3 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3781 Maximillian Mouse (Handyman)''' ** 4 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3782 Paul Parrot (Press Raccoon and His Sports Car (Roger Raccoon With Sports Car)''' ** 16 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3627 Bonnie Bunny (Bonny Rabbit)''' ** 18 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3637 Gertrude Goat the Painter (Gertrude Goat)''' ** 14 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3638/3642 Buster Bulldog (Fire Engine)''' ** 17 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3709 Henry Horse the Carpenter (Henry Horse)''' ** 2 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3710 Patrick Panda (Peter Panda)''' ** 2 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3787 Hannah Hippopotamus the Public Gardener (Hannah Hippo)''' ** 8 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3788 Paulette Poodle's Living Room''' ** 12 pieces, 1 minifig ===1984 Sets=== * '''801 Fabuland Characters''' ** 2 minifigs * '''3639/3643 "Paddy" Wagon (Police Van)''' ** 9 pieces, 2 minifigs * '''3664 Bertie Bulldog Police Chief and Constable Bulldog (Police Station)''' ** 63 pieces, 2 minifigs * '''3670 Service Station''' ** 52 pieces, 2 minifigs * '''3671 Airport''' ** 49 pieces, 3 minifigs * '''3711 Tubby and Tuba (Tuba Player)''' ** 4 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3712 Robby Rabbit (Accordion Player)''' ** 4 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3713 Mike Monkey (Drummer)''' ** 7 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3789 Constable Clarke (Speed Cop)''' ** 5 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3791 Wally Walrus (Scooter Tourist)''' ** 6 pieces, 1 minifig ===1985 Sets=== * '''3624 Flower Car (Pick Up Truck)''' (same as 3627) ** 19 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3625/3630 Sandy Seagull's ** 99 pieces, 4 minifigs * '''3714 Workman and Barrow (Bricklayer)''' ** 6 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3715 Hannah's Flower Stand (Hippo With Flower Stand)''' ** 14 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3716 Telephone (Fox At Office)''' ** 8 pieces, 1 minifig * '''Mouse in a Tub Fishing (Angler)''' ** 9 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3792 Lisa Lamb's Bedroom (Bedroom)''' ** 14 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3793 Boris Bulldog and Mailbox (Post Office)''' ** 12 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3794 Police Motorcycle (Bulldog on Motorcycle)''' ** 14 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3795 Catherine Cat in Her Kitchen (Catherine Cat's Kitchen/Kitchen)''' ** 28 pieces, 1 minifig ===1986 Sets=== * '''1570 Fabuland Character Polybag''' ** 4 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3633 Motor Boat With Walter Walrus (Captain Walrus in His Motor Boat)''' ** 13 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3644 Mike Monkey and His Taxi (Mayor's Car)''' ** 10 pieces, 2 minifigs * '''3668 Merry-Go-Round With Ticket Booth (Merry-Go-Round)''' ** 42 pieces, 3 minifigs * '''3679 Flour Mill and Shop (Mill With Shop)''' ** 73 pieces, 2 minifigs * '''3718 Outdoor Cafe With Bonnie Bunny (Outdoor Cafe)''' ** 6 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3796 Patricia Piglet at Her Bakery (Patricia Piglet's Bakery/Little Bakery)''' ** 30 pieces, 1 minifig ===1987 Sets=== * '''1516 Promotional Set (Theatre)''' ** 23 pieces, 2 minifigs * '''3636 Lucy Lamb's Bedroom (Lucy Lamb in Her Bedroom)''' ** 21 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3645 School Room (Classroom)''' ** 24 pieces, 3 minifigs * '''3659 Playground''' ** 16 pieces, 2 minifigs * '''3662 Double-Decker Bus (Bus)''' ** 32 pieces, 2 minifigs * '''3674 Bonny Bunnie's New House''' ** 44 pieces, 2 minifigs * '''3675 General Store''' ** 103 pieces, 3 minifigs * '''3682 Fire Station''' ** 149 pieces, 3 minifigs * '''3719 Bus Stop With Maximilian Mouse (Bus Stop)''' ** 5 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3797 Fire Chief Barty Bulldog''' ** 8 pieces, 1 minifig ===1988 Sets=== * '''3622 Rowboat With Lionel Lion and Hannah Hippopotamus (Rowboat)''' ** 12 pieces, 2 minifigs * '''3623 Beauty Salon''' ** 24 pieces, 2 minifigs * '''3646 Catherine Cat in Her Kitchen (Walrus & Cat in the Kitchen)''' ** 53 pieces, 2 minifigs * '''3680 Caravan and Rowboat (Camping in New Caravan)''' ** 27 pieces, 3 minifigs * '''3683 Amusement Park''' ** 93 pieces, 4 minifigs * '''3721 Clive Crocodile on His Skateboard (Crocodile on Skateboard)''' ** 10 pieces, 1 minifig * '''3798 Hannah Hippopotamus on a Picnic (Hippo Goes Picnicing)''' ** 24 pieces, 1 minifig ===1989 Sets=== * '''3647 Lionel Lion's Classroom''' ** 42 pieces, 3 minifigs * '''3663 Max Mouse's Merry-Go-Round (Merry-Go-Round)''' ** 23 pieces, 2 minifigs * '''3676 Cathy Cat's Fun Park''' ** 43 pieces, 4 minifigs == Books == Instructions for sets contained text stories with illustrations. This was the first time Lego used inspirational material. There were also printed story books based on Lego Fabuland theme. These include Edward's Skyscraper, The Missing Fireworks, Catherine Cat's Birthday, Billy Bear's Holiday, Ricky at the Restaurant, Charlie Cat's Flying Circus, Lionel Lion's New Car, Morty's New Job, Henry's Night Out, The Flower Song, Edward's Butterfly, The Birthday Present, The Burblies, The Troll in the Mountain, The Fabuland Rainbow (released with a poster and a vinyl record), Max & Edward All At Sea, Adventure in the Dark, The Red Ball, The Whirlwind, The Snowstorm, The Secret Trip, Edward Elephant, Bonnie Bunny, Lionel Lion, Boris Bulldog, Marjorie Mouse, Mortimer Mouse, Doctor Dog, Freddy Fox, Gertrude Goat, Catherine Cat, Doctor Lucy Lamb, Barty Bulldog, Henry Horse, Paul Parrot, Billy Bear, Hannah Hippopotamus. Additionally [[Edward and Friends#Books|seven books]] were released, based on Fabuland TV series "Edward and Friends". The comic strip "Fabuland, the Country of Fantasies" was included in the Italian magazine ''Più e il suo Gioco''. == Other products == For the Fabuland theme Lego introduced such licensed products as key chains, table decorations, [[pen]]s, playing cards, jigsaw puzzles, [[Concentration (game)|memory games]] (in association with [[Ravensburger]]), parachute toys, children cutlery sets (in association with [[J. A. Henckels|BSF]]), bed cover sheets, children’s clothing. Fabuland characters were attached to [[Nestlé]]'s Orzoro jars. In 1979 in Germany [[Phonogram Inc.]] released on [[vinyl record]] radioplay "Stories from Fabuland" written by Sebastian Beck and directed by Michael Weckler. == External links == * [http://brickset.com/sets/theme-Fabuland Fabuland] on '''Brickset'''. ==Notes== {{reflist|refs= {{Cite book|last = Lipkowitz|first = Daniel|title = The Lego Book|publisher = Dorling Kindersley|year = 2009|pages = 126|isbn = 978-1-4053-4169-1}} {{cite book|title=Fabuland 3679|date=1986|publisher=Lego Group|location=Germany}} {{cite web |url=https://www.lego.com/en-us/legohistory/fabuland |title=Lego Fabuland history |author= |date= |website=www.lego.com |publisher=Lego Group |accessdate=2017-09-15}} {{cite web |url=https://brickset.com/sets/3695-1/Figure-collection |title=Exact contents and availability not known. It could possibly have been a promotional or shop display set. |author= |date= |website=brickset.com |publisher= |accessdate=2017-09-13}} {{cite web |url=http://mikimoz.blogspot.com/2017/01/costruzioni-lego-fabuland.html |title=Lego Fabuland |author= |date=2017-01-26 |website=mikimoz.blogspot.com |publisher= |accessdate=2017-10-04}} {{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K5YgUB_-vak |title=Nestlé Orzoro Fabuland TV Commercial 1985 |author= |date=2016-01-30 |website=www.youtube.com |publisher= |accessdate=2017-10-04}} {{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qxCSTlvrQ1w |title=Nestlé Orzoro Fabuland TV Commercial 1987 |author= |date=2016-01-30 |website=www.youtube.com |publisher= |accessdate=2017-10-04}} }} {{Lego}} [[Category:Lego themes|Fabuland]] [[Category:Toy animals]] [[Category:Products introduced in 1979]] [[Category:Products and services discontinued in 1989]]

==Human turning into an animal== {{main|Clinical lycanthropy}} * [[Berserker]] (werebear) * [[Animagus]] * [[Werecat]] * [[Werehyena]] * [[Skin-walker]] * Nanaue (wereshark) * [[Werewolf]] * Púca * [[Nagual]] * Kanima - A snake like creature that appears in season 2 of Teen Wolf, claws contain a paralytic toxin that renders its victims essentially helpless * [[Wendigo]]- mythical man-eating monster that shows up in season 1 of Supernatural * Werecoyote * Werejaguar * Odiyan * [[Merfolk (disambiguation)|Merpeople]] *[[Chimaera]]
==Animal turning into a human== * [[Bakeneko]] (cat) * [[Boto]] and [[Encantado (mythology)|Encantado]] (river dolphin) * [[Jorōgumo]] (spider) * [[Kitsune]], [[Huli Jing]] and [[Kumiho]] (fox) * [[Legend of the White Snake|Lady White Snake]], [[Ichchhadhari Nag]] and [[Yuxa]] (snake) * [[Myrmidons]] (ant) * [[Pipa Jing]] (jade pipa) * [[Selkie]] (seal) * [[Tanuki]] (racoon dog) * [[Tsuru no Ongaeshi|Tsuru Nyōbō]] (crane) * [[Toyotama-hime]] (crocodile or shark) * Inkling (from ''[[Splatoon]]'') * [[Kushtaka]] (Otter)
==Other== * [[Ala (demon)|Ala]] * [[Demon]] * [[Aswang]] * [[Changeling]] * Cybertronian (from ''[[Transformers]]'') * [[Doppelgänger]] * [[Empousa]] * Grimm (from ''[[RWBY]]'') * Hemkas (from ''[[Hanazuki: Full of Treasures]]'') * [[Lamia (mythology)|Lamia]] * [[Manananggal]] * [[Kulam|Mangkukulam]] * [[It (character)| Pennywise]] (from ''[[Stephen King's It]]'') * [[Rakshasa]] * [[Rokurokubi]] * [[Shen (clam-monster)|Shen]] * [[Spriggan]] * [[Tengu]] * [[The Honking|Were-car]] (from ''[[Futurama]]'') * [[Yaksha]] *Tree Figure- Unknown of the name to call this creature, unlucky victims fall to the peril of what people named “Sebastian The Figure” for giggles among them. Location, dates, and all information was lost on this subject and is being recovered at all costs. *Tiyanak- Philippine monster that disguises themselves as a lone baby in an empty or unlikely place, prompting the human who finds them to take them home. Once home, though, the tiyanak will kill the human.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Shapeshifters}} [[Category:Legendary creatures]] [[Category:Shapeshifting| ]]

revision.text:
{{About||similar honors awarded in other countries|Living National Treasure (disambiguation){{!}}Living National Treasure}} {{Infobox Korean name |img = |hangul = 인간문화재 (중요무형문화재보유자) |hanja = {{linktext|人|間|文|化|財}} ({{linktext|重|要|無|形|文|化|財|保|有|者}}) |rr = Inganmunhwajae (Jungyomuhyeongmunhwajaeboyuja) |mr = Inkanmunhwachae (Chungyomuhyŏngmunhwachaepoyucha) }}
A '''Living National Treasure''' (인간문화재; 人間文化財 ; ingan munhwage, literally, ''human cultural asset'') is a [[South Korea]]n popular term for those individuals certified as '''Holders of [[Intangible Cultural Property (South Korea)|Important Intangible Cultural Properties]]''' (중요무형문화재보유자 ; 重要無形文化財保有者; Jungyomuhyeongmunhwajaeboyuja), also known as ''keepers'', by the [[Ministry of Education (South Korea)|Ministry of Education]] as based on South Korea's Law for the Protection of Cultural Properties (文化財保護法).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.koreana.or.kr/months/news_view.asp?b_idx%3D2243%26lang%3Den%26page_type%3Dlist |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-07-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140531124737/http://www.koreana.or.kr/months/news_view.asp?b_idx=2243&lang=en&page_type=list |archivedate=2014-05-31 |df= }}</ref><ref>http://www.koreana.or.kr/months/news_view.asp?b_idx=2244&lang=en&page_type=list</ref> The term "Living National Treasure" is not formally mentioned in the law, but is an informal term referencing the cultural properties designated as the [[National Treasure (South Korea)|National Treasures]].
== History == The government started taking steps after the Second World War and the Korean War to protect the intangible heritage of the country.<ref>http://www.koreana.or.kr/months/news_view.asp?b_idx=2244&lang=en&page_type=list</ref>
The term was coined in 1960 by the young reporter Ye Yong-hae, who published a number of series in the ''[[Hankook Ilbo]]'' newspaper, highlighting the plight of artisans and artists who were either neglected or even persecuted under the regime of President Park under the ''[[Misin tapa undong]]'' modernization drive that was destroying the old traditional beliefs and fabrics of villages. In a growing recognition of the worthiness of protecting the old Korean traditions and culture, a law was passed to protect the intangible cultural heritage and the masters and artisans who were keeping it alive.<ref>http://www.koreana.or.kr/months/news_view.asp?b_idx=2244&lang=en&page_type=list</ref>
Over time the number of keepers of this heritage grew, but the list was also subject to criticism about the exact criteria and nomination process.
The latest Important Intangible Cultural Property is ''bun-wa-jang'', a traditional Korean roof building skill, which was designated in 2008. With the designation, Lee Geon-bok was approved as an ''ingan-munhwage'' in 2008. According to [[Jeon Byung-hon]] of the [[Democratic Party (South Korea, 2008)|Democratic Party]], twelve Important Intangible Cultural Properties of Korea have not had any ''ingan-munhwage'' for more than 10 years.
== Definition == A Living National Treasure is a person with the ability to make or perform one of the officially designated Important [[Intangible Cultural Property (South Korea)|Intangible Cultural Properties]]. Intangible culture assets are organized within 108 different aspects of Korean traditional culture, from traditional dance to building techniques. The ministry draws the list and puts the artist under its protection. It is advised by the [[Cultural Heritage Administration]] under the Cultural Properties Protection Law. Once people are designated as an holders, they have rights to government support for transmission of their cultural performance and have responsibility to show that ability and train younger students. The designation expires with his or her death.
== List == Presently it has designated a total of 570 holders of these intangible properties.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.koreana.or.kr/months/news_view.asp?b_idx%3D2243%26lang%3Den%26page_type%3Dlist |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-07-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140531124737/http://www.koreana.or.kr/months/news_view.asp?b_idx=2243&lang=en&page_type=list |archivedate=2014-05-31 |df= }}</ref>
* Han Bongnyeo (한복려 ; 韓福麗), chef, holder of Intangible Cultural Property No. 38 ([[Korean royal court cuisine]])<ref name="hancinema">{{cite web|url=http://www.hancinema.net/special-interview--han-bok-ryeo-master-of-korean-royal-cuisine-21540.html|title=Special Interview - Han Bok-Ryeo, Master of Korean Royal Cuisine|date=2009-12-07|publisher=Hancinema|accessdate=2013-05-10}}</ref><ref name="ktinterjú">{{cite web|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/art/2008/03/135_21068.html|title=Vive La Korean Food! Hallyu Revitalizes Culinary Tradition|publisher=The Korea Times|date=2008-03-20|accessdate=2013-05-10}}</ref> * Jung Gwan-Chae, dyer, holder of Intangible Cultural Property No. 115 (''[[yeomsaek]]'')<ref>http://www.arirang.co.kr/News/News_View.asp?nseq=109443&category=2</ref> * [[Kim Bak-young]] (김박영 ; 金博榮), bowmaker, holder of Intangible Cultural Property No. 47 (''[[gakgung]]'')<ref>http://navercast.naver.com/contents.nhn?rid=92&contents_id=10563&category_type=series</ref> * Kim Deokhwan (김덕환 ; 金德煥), gold leaf artisan, holder of Intangible Cultural Property No. 199 (''[[geumbak]]'')<ref>http://www.hani.co.kr/arti/culture/culture_general/157132.html</ref> * [[Kim Sook-ja]], [[Korean dance#Folk dance|salpuri]] dancer, official guardian of Intangible Cultural Property No. 97.<ref name=lee>{{cite book | chapter=The Concept of Korean Folk Dance | author-last=Lee | author-first=Byoung-ok | title=Korean Folk Dance | date=2009 | translator-last=Cho | translator-first=Yoon-jung | p=144}}</ref> * Kim Tong Yon, bamboo craftsman<ref>http://www.gettyimages.com.au/detail/news-photo/south-korea-people-men-portrait-of-kim-tong-yon-a-master-news-photo/481591933</ref> * Kim Youngjae, musician, holder of Intangible Cultural Property No.16 (''[[geomungo sanjo]]'')<ref>http://www.koreanculture.org/?document_srl=565972</ref><ref>http://www.koreasociety.org/arts-culture/performing-arts/master_kim_youngjae_a_living_national_treasure.html</ref> * [[Yu Geun-Hyeong]] (유근형 ; 柳根瀅), ceramist, holder of Intangible Cultural Property No.13 ([[Koryo Celadon]])<ref>https://www.britishmuseum.org/research/search_the_collection_database/term_details.aspx?bioId=140564</ref><ref>https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0079414/</ref><ref>https://www.amazon.de/Koryo-celadon-autobiography-Keun-Hyeong-transparent/dp/B0088GGNLI</ref><ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Fq8eBghuOLA</ref>
== See also == * [[Heritage preservation in South Korea]] * [[Living National Treasure (Japan)]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links == *[https://web.archive.org/web/20111010030419/http://www.cha.go.kr/main/KorIndex!korMain.action Korean Cultural Heritage Administration] *[http://www2.enewstoday.co.kr/sub_read.html?uid=246238&section=sc1 Disappearing Ingan-munhwage article] * http://congress.aks.ac.kr/korean/files/2_1358750273.pdf * https://www.unesco.or.kr/upload/data_center/2002%20인간문화재제도설립관련운영지침(영문).pdf
{{Heritage preservation in South Korea}}

{{Infobox award | name = Malaysia Kalai Ulagam Awards | image = | imagesize = | caption = | current_awards = Malaysia Kalai Ulagam Award 2016 |description = Outstanding achievements within the [[Malaysian Indian]] [[Malaysian Tamil cinema|Entertainment]] Scene | presenter = Malaysia Kalai Ulagam | country = [[Malaysia]] | network = [[YouTube]] | year = 2015 | website = {{URL|https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC_DvlbY3bbyAy9J27EjerwQ|Malaysia Kalai Ulagam}} }} '''''Malaysia Kalai Ulagam Award''''' or acronym known as '''''MUK Award''''' is the Malaysian online award ceremony to pay tribute and award the key industry player within [[Malaysian Indian]] community who have been working hard to keep the local entertainment industry of Malaysia alive.<ref>http://m.thestar.com.my/story.aspx?hl=Awards+honours+the+best+in+local+Indian+entertainment+scene&sec=metro&id=%7BDB933E63-F602-4F75-A69B-E8A45040DD6A%7D</ref> This award were presented by online entertainment show, Malaysia Kalai Ulagam.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC_DvlbY3bbyAy9J27EjerwQ</ref> The current award for 2016 will be held on 25 February.<ref>http://friendzcab.blogspot.my/2015/11/malaysian-kalai-ulagam-awards-2016.html</ref>
==Categories== {| class="wikitable" | |- !align="center"|Most Popular and lifetime awards. !align="center"|Movie Category |- | * Most Popular Artiste *Lifetime Achievement Award | *Best Movie * Best Actor * Best Actress * Best Male Supporting Actor * Best Female Supporting Actress * Best Male Newcomer * Best Female Newcomer * Best Comedian * Best Lyrics writer * Best Music Director * Best Director * Best Male Singer * Best Female Singer * Best Song * Best Cinematographer * Best Stunt Master * Best Editor |- !align="center"|Telemovie and DVD category !align="center"|Short Movie category |- | * Best Telemovie * Best Actor * Best Actress * Best Male Supporting Actor * Best Female Supporting Actress * Best Music Director * Best Director * Best Cinematographer | * Best Short Movie * Best Actor * Best Actress * Best Male Supporting Actor * Best Lyrics writer * Best Music Director * Best Director * Best Song * Best Cinematographer * Best Video Song |}

Perakas]] ([[Vennira Iravuggal]]) * Best Male Singer: [[Dhilip Varman]] (En Uyire – Vetti Pasanga) * Best Female Singer: Renuka Shree (Ore Oru Sollil – Vetti Pasanga) * Best Song: Azhagana Pani Katru (Victory) * Best Cinematographer: Mano V.Narayanan (Vennira Iravuggal) * Best Stunt Master: Ruben (Victory) * Best Editor: Prem Nath ([[Maindhan (2014 film)|Maindhan]])
